Gịnị bụ ihea anyị na-ahụ?Nnwa puusu tọrọ n'osisi. 
Paul sịrị, “A ga m aga zọpụta ya.”

Paul jụrụ Mama, sị, “Mọọmii, anyị ọ ga-edebenwu ya? E tinye nanị otua na ndị anyị nwere.”Ọ pụta puusu ole?Iteghete (9).
Mama Paul wee sị, “Puusu iteghete karịrị.”

English: DeviAgain! Again!I want to knock it down again!Bonda does it. He makes a box tower.He does a good job.He does not smile.He does not frown.
DeviVroom! Vroom!BAM!And she knocks it down again!!!Bonda laughsand claps.He does this every time.Bonda is my best friend.A perfect friend for a girl in a wheelchair!
DeviHi! I'm Devi. I'm from the future! The year 2085.So much has changed since your time.Today, technology makes life wonderful!
DeviMeet Bonda. My best friend. A ROBOT.Did you guess that? Who else would build a tower 50 times?Bonda never gets bored!
DeviBonda can do many things.He can get my secret box from the top shelf.He can lift Baba's desk to find my earring.Things like that.
BondaHumans are useless!Your legs and arms cannot grow taller.My arms have cameras and telescopes!

DeviI have to train Bonda.I "program" him.I show him how to do things.Like on Sunday, I wanted my box.First, I sent Bonda to the shelf. Bonda's screen has a map of my house. I drew the path to the shelf with my finger on the map.Next, I told him to reach up and scan the top shelf.His camera finger took pictures.

DeviBonda showed me the pictures he took.I touched the picture of the box I wanted."That is my secret box, Bonda," I said.Can you bring it to me?Now, I only have to say, "Secret box!" And off he goes.Once Bonda learns, he never forgets. Not like humans!
DeviSo, that is my best friend.I have human friends too.We play and fight and go to school.But I love Bonda best. He never gets mad at me!
DeviRobots do not have feelings.But, shhh! Don't tell Bonda I said that!It might make him feel bad!BondaThat is not logical, Devi!If I do not have feelings, how can I feel bad?Silly humans. Pah!

DeviThe best part is, I have Bonda all to myself! I never get jealous. Because I am his only friend!BondaThat is not true. I have other robot friends! Wait! Does Devi only like me BECAUSE she thinks I have no friends? And no feelings? Oh no! I feel mad, and sad, and...

DeviBonda, are you okay? You are getting hot! You are not working!I will take care of you now. I will shut you down. It will be like going to sleep. Then I will start you again.BondaDevi's eyes are wet. She is sad. I feel sad. But, wet eyes mean she cares about me.So I also feel happy! I feel happy-sad.
Whirr! Hum! Bonda reboots.DeviBonda? Bonda, do you hear me?Is your memory gone? I want you to remember our fun! Our love...
BondaAha! Love. That sad-happy feeling is love!
BondaHi, Devi!What can I do?Do you want me to stack the boxes?Do you want me to get your secret box?DeviOh, Bonda!You're all right!I am so glad!
BondaI do something very odd.No one programmed me to do it.I wrap my arms around my friend, Devi.This is not logical!

Who or what is a robot?A robot is “any electro-mechanical machine guided by a computer program or electronic circuits." It doesn't have to look like a human. There are robots all around us, already!Really? Where?Well, they are in factories, warehouses, orchards, hospitals and even homes. They may look like large mechanical arms.Car factories use these for welding, gluing and painting car parts. Or they may look like tiny cameras, attached to thin hair-like tubes,.Hospitals use these to entering our intestines and arteries to check them out. Some robots look like flat round discs, buzzing around.Homes and offices use these to clean floors at night when everyone is asleep. Some look like small wheeled vehicles, going into war zones.Soldiers use these to find dangerous landmines.Other robots roll across the surfaces of the moon or Mars.They take pictures and sendsamples to send to scientists back on Earth.Will there be a Bonda for every Devi by the year 2085? We'll have to wait and see!

Have you ever seen a robot?If you have ever used, or even seen, a computer or a smartphone, you have 'seen' a robot!Yes, they are in those devices as well. Some of them even have names, like Siri and Cortana.They can help us find useful information for school projects, traffic reports and more. They can book our bus and train tickets, and order our groceries.They can even tell us exactly how many calories we have burnt after a game of football!What does the future of robots look like? We may not have robots walking our streets in India by 2040.But we will definitely be surrounded by robots of one kind or another without knowing it. It is quite likely that there will be driverless “robot” cars on our streets. We may have microscopic robots in our contact lenses that help us take pictures.We won't even have to hold our phones or cameras up to take them.But how will we take selfies?? And little airborne robots called drones will be flying all around.They will deliver letters, packages and kababs, putting delivery boys out of business!As for 2085, 45 years AFTER that, who knows what robots will be up to?
Igbo:
"Nyeghachi ha! Bonda! Achọrọ m ịnwale ịkụda ha site n'akụkụ dị iche!"N'egbughị oge, n'enweghị ịgbagwoju anya, Bonda weghaara igbe nke a kwatara akwata n'elu nke ọzọ maka oge nke iri ise. Ụlọ elu dị elu, nke na-ama jijiji, nke naanị Bonda maara otú e si ewu ya 
guzo ọtọ

M na - agbanye nnukwu ígwè turbo engine - vrooom, VROOM - ọ dị ka égbè. BAM! Enwere m obi ụtọ, ebe ọ bụ na ụlọ elu ahụ gbawaraBonda na-achị ọchị, na-akụ aka ya dị ka o siri mee na oge nke mbụ m mere nke a.Ezigbo Bonda. Ezigbo enyi onye ọ bụla nwere ike inwe. Karịsịa onye dị afọ iri n'oche nkwagharị.

Kedu. Abụ m Devi, m si n'afọ 2085 AD. Nna nna m na-ekwukarị otú ụwa si gbanwee kemgbe ọ bụ ọgbọ m, azụ na 2016. Enwere ọtụtụ mmadụ ugbu a, ma ikuku, adịghị emetọ, n'ihi na ọtụtụ ụgbọ ala na-agba ọsọ na ọkụ eletrik ma ọ bụ ike anyanwụ.E nwere ihe mberede dị ole na ole, n'ihi na ụgbọala na-ebugharị onwe ha, ha na-akpachara anya. Enweghi oke osisi na oke ohia karia ka odi n'oge gara aga, mana ana 
na-akụ osisi ọhụrụ mgbe nile, nke di nma.
Mana ihe gbanwere n'ezie, ka nna m ochie kwuru, bụ nkà na ụzụ. E nwere nkà na ụzụ na 2016 kwa, ma ọ dịghị ihe yiri ihe anyị nwere ugbu a. o mere n'ezie ndụ dị ebube.Ọ bụ nkà na ụzụ nke nyere m ezi enyi m

Zute Bonda. Ezigbo enyi ruo mgbe ebighi ebi, ndị na-ewu ụlọ cardboard dị iche iche, na ROBOT. 

M na-ahụ ka anya gị meghere. Ha! Ị cheghị nke ahụ? Ma chee banyere ya. Kedu enyi nke ọzọ ga-eji obi ụtọ wuru gị ụlọ elu ugboro 50 n'emeghị mkpesa? Kedu enyi ọzọ ga-ewu ya n'ụzọ zuru oke n'oge ọ bụla?
Bonda: Ekwenyere m! Ụmụ mmadụ adịghị arụ ọrụ dịka anyị dị. Ha na-eme mkpesa na ime otu ihe ahụ ugboro ugboro. (Amaghị m ihe okwu ahụ pụtara, n'ihi ya, ajụla m!). Ha na-ada ọrịa, ọ dịkwa mkpa ịga ụlọ mposi ọtụtụ. M na-eche otú ha si mee ihe ọ bụla tupu anyị abịa!

Iwuru ụlọ elu abụghị naanị ihe Bonda nwere ike ime. Enwere m ike ịzụ ya ịme ọtụtụ ihe ndị ọzọ  

- weta igbe m dị na nzuzo n'ebe dị elu (nke dị elu nke na ọ dịghị onye ọzọ nwere iweta ya), bulie oche Nna m ka m wee hụ ebe obere ọla ntị ọlaedo m gbapụ (Mama ga-eti mkpu ruo ọtụtụ ma ọ bụrụ na efunahụ m ya) ... Ihe dị otú ahụ.

Bonda: Dị ka m kwuru, ụmụ mmadụ abaghị uru ma e jiri ya tụnyere anyị robots. ụmụ mmadụ na-arapara n'otu ebe na ogologo, ma anyị nwere ike ito ogologo ma dị mkpụmkpụ karịa uche anyị, site na ịgbatị ma ọ bụ belata ogwe aka anyị na ụkwụ anyị. Anya anyị nwere ike ịbụ igwefoto, telescopes, microscopes, ma ọ bụ atọ a tụgharịrị n'otu

Kedu ka m ga esi azụ Bonda? Site na "mmemme" ya. Mmemme pụtara igosi ya, otu ugboro, otu ihe mere. Dịka ọmụmaatụ, n'ụbọchị nke ọzọ, achọrọ m ka ọ wetara m igbe akụ nzuzo m, nke m kwurula na mbụ. Lee otú m si mee ya.
Nke mbụ, m gwara Bonda ebe ọ dị adị, wee depụta ụzọ nke ụlọ m ọ na-egosiputa na mkpado ya.
"Ị nwere ike ịbịakwute ma chọpụta akara n'elu ugbu a, B?" M kwuru mgbe ọ bịara n'ebe ahụ. Ogwe aka ya gbapụrụ elu. Ka ọ na-agbatị aka ya n'ogologo nke ala ahụ, obere igwefoto dị na mkpịsị aka ya gafeere, na-ese foto nke ihe niile n'ebe ahụ

Mgbe o gosipụtara m foto ndị ahụ, nanị m metụrụ foto nke igbe m chọrọ. "Nke ahụ bụ igbe nchekwa nzuzo m, Bonda," ka m kwuru. "Ị nwere ike iwetara m ya?"Ugbu a, mgbe ọ bụla m chọrọ igbe ahụ, naanị m ga-asị, "igbe nchekwa akụ!" ma ọ na-aga, na-enweta ya. Ozugbo ọ "mụtara" ihe, Bonda apụghị ichezọ. Ncheta ya dị egwu!Bonda: Naanị ụmụ mmadụ, ndị na-enweghị ike icheta ebe ha hapụrụ igodo ha, iko ha, igwe ha ...

Ee, nke ahụ bụ otú ezigbo enyi m dị. Ma ee, abụ m nwata nwanyị nwere nnọọ ihu ọchị. Oh, ghara nghọtahie. Enwere m ndị enyi mmadụ bụ ndị m na-egwuri egwu ma na-alụ ọgụ ma na-aga akwụkwọ. Ma, m hụrụ Bonda n'anya karịa ha niile, n'ihi na ọ naghị ada mbà mgbe obim na-atọ ụtọ na onye ọzọ, ma ọ bụ na-ekwo ekworo mgbe m merie ya na maths, ma ọ bụ iwe mgbe m chefuo ya ụbọchị ọmụmụ ...Nke a bụ n'ihi ... Bonda enweghị mmetụta ọ bụla! Ma ekwula ya n'olu dara ụda - o nwere ike ime ka o nwee mwute

Bonda: Tsk, tsk, Devi, olee ebe i chere echiche? Ị na-ekwu na enweghị m mmetụta, mgbe ahụ ị na-echegbu onwe gị na m "ga enwe mwute". Ụmụ mmadụ nwere ike ịbụ ezi ihe na uche, ma mgbe ha malitere inwe mmetụta, ezi uche agbagha pụha! Mba! Ònye chọrọ inwe mmetụta ndị a?Chere! Nke a ọ bụ "mmetụta" m chere ugbu a? Nhazi m gwara m na ọ bụ. Ọ na-agwa m na m na-eche ihe a na-akpọ "mmejọ" ... Hmm ... Amaghị m otú m ga-esi "nwee mmetụta" banyere nke ahụ

Oh, ma ebe a bụ akụkụ kasịsị mma - Enweghị m iwe ọ bụla na ya na enyi ọzọ na-ekpori ndụ karịa m, n'ihi na ... ọ nweghị ihe ọ bụla! Bonda: Hey, hey, nke a abụghị eziokwu - enwere m ndị enyi ndị ọzọ! Onye na-edozi robot na cafe na agwam "Ndewo" nke ọma, nwa okorobịa na-ahụ maka ihe ndị na-ere na ahịa robot na ekele kwam.Chere na nkeji ... Ọ bụ na m ka na-eme ihe Devi na-ekwu , ka ghọta ... ọ na-amasị Devi naanị n'ihi na enweghị m enyi ndị ọzọ - NA enweghị mmetụta! Ọ bụghị n'ihi onye m bụ! Oh ee! Ọ na-adị m ka ọ na - enwe mmetụta na iwe, na ...

"Bonda! Ị dị mma? Ị na-ekpo ọkụ, Bonda - ị nwere ahụ ọkụ! "Ma echegbula, enyi m, m ga-elekọta gị dị ka ị na-elekọta m mgbe niile. Gee ntị nke ọma ugbu a, Bonda - m ga-emechie gị ugbu a ka usoro gị wee gbakee, ọ dị mma? Atụla ụjọ - ọ ga-adị ka ịrahụ ụra. Mgbe m malitere ịmaliteghachi, ị ga-alọghachi, dị mma dịka ọhụụ, anyị ga-abụ ezigbo ndị enyi.Bonda: Anya Devi niile na-agba mmiri, dị ka ha na dị mgbe ọ na enwe mwute, ma ọ bụ na-atụ ụjọ. Nke ahụ na-eme ka m nwee mmetụta dị mwute. Ma onye nhazi m gwara m na anya mmiri ya na-egosi na ọ na-eche echiche ọma banyere m. Ugbu a, enwere m obi uto ... Enwere m mgbagwoju anya ... enwere m obi ụtọ ... Ana m emechi ugbu a ....

Enwere obere ụda dị ka Bonda na-ebili. Ma anya mmiri na agba'm."Bonda?" m na-ekwu. "Bonda, ị na - anụ olu m? Ị maara onye m bụ? Biko gwa m na ị na - echeta ihe niile! Achọrọ m ka ị cheta ihe ọchị niile anyị nwere n'afọ gara aga, ịhụnanya niile ..."
Bonda: A-ha! Ịhụnanya. Nke ahụ ọ bụ mmetụta m na-enwe, obi ụtọ na-ewute n'otu oge ahụ?
"Kedu Devi! Gini ka i choro ka m meere gi taa? Ka anyi gwuegwu, ikpo igbe a? M ga - ewetara gi igbe nzuzo gi? I choro ...""Bonda! Ị dị mma! Ee, obi dị m ezigbo ụtọ!"Ejide aka Bonda ma jidesie ya ike.
Bonda: Mgbe ahụ, m na-eme ihe dị mgbagwoju anya nye m, ihe onye ọ bụla na-emebeghị ka m mee. Ejide re'm enyi m Devi, na enweghị ezi ihe kpatara ya.

ROBOTS: ụnyaahụ, taa na echi 
Enwere Bonda maka nwa ọ bụla n'afọ 2085? Anyị ga-echere ma hụ, ma ọ dịghị ihe ọ bụla ịgọnahụ na a ga-ahụkarị ndị ọrụ robot ọbụna n'ime afọ 25yrs site ugbu a,  n'afọ 2040.


Ònye ma obu ihe bu robot?


Ọ bụrụ na ị kwuru na robot bụ igwe nke na - ele anya ma na - eme dị ka mmadụ, ma ọ bụrụ na ọ na - emegharị, nwere okwu dị nro, enweghị nkwupụta, na anya nke na - emegharị mgbe ọ gbanwere, ị na - ele ọtụtụ fim na ihe ngosi TVN'ihi na, n'ezie, robot bụ "igwe ọ bụla electro mechanical na-eduzi ihe omume kọmputa ma ọ bụ sekit kọmputa." Ọ dịghị mkpa ka ọ dị ka mmadụ ma ọlị. Nke a mere na ị gaghị aghọta na e nwere robots gburugburu anyị, ugbua! N'ezie? Ebee?
Ha dị n'ụlọ nkwakọba ihe, ụlọ nkwakọba akụ, ubi mkpụrụ osisi, ụlọ ọgwụ na ụlọ ọ bụla. Ha nwere ike ịdị ka nnukwu ngwá agha, dịka ndị na-arụpụta ụgbọ ala, ịgbado ọkụ, ịkwanye na eserese ụgbọ ala. Ma ọ bụ, ha nwere ike ịdị ka obere igwefoto, dịka ndị nọ n'ụlọ ọgwụ, na-etinye aka na tubes dị ka ntutu isi, na-abanye eriri afọ anyị na akwara iji chọpụta ha maka nsogbu.  Ụfọdụ ndị na-arụ ọrụ ụgbọ oloko dị ka diski dị elu, na-arụ ọrụ na ụlọ na ọfịs, na-agbagharị ma na-ehicha ụlọ n'abalị mgbe mmadụ nile na-ehi ụra. Ụfọdụ dị ka obere ụgbọ ala, na-aga n'ókèala agha, na-achọta ala ndị dị ize ndụ, ma ọ bụ na-agafe n'elu ọnwa ma ọ bụ Mars, na-ewere foto ma na-anakọta ihe atụ iji zipụ ndị ọkà mmụta sayensị na Ụwa.

M ga-achọ ka m hụ otu robot n'onwe m!Ọ bụrụ na i jirila, ma ọ bụ ọbụna hụrụ, kọmputa maọbụ smartphone, ị 'hụrụ' robot! Ee, ha nọkwa na ngwaọrụ ndị ahụ. Ụfọdụ n'ime ha ọbụna nwere aha, dị ka Siri na Cortana (ị nụla ha?). Ha nwere ike inyere anyị aka ịchọta ozi bara uru - ihe maka ọrụ ụlọ akwụkwọ, akụkọ okporo ụzọ (nke ụzọ nwere ọtụtụ ụgbọala taa?) Olee ụzọ dị mma ị ga - esi gaa?), Ntụrụndụ (ebee ka fim ọhụrụ ahụ na - aga? ), na ọtụtụ ndị ọzọ. Ha nwedịrị ike inyere gị aka ịzụta tiketi ụgbọ ala anyị na ụgbọ oloko n'oge, zipu maka ihe oriri anyị na ụlọ ahịa, ma gwa anyị kpọmkwem calorie ole anyị kwụsịrị mgbe egwuregwu egwuregwuKedu ihe ga-eme n'ọdịnihu nke ndị robots? Kedu ihe ụwa ga-adị ka, site na, sị, 2040, gbasara robots?
Anyị nwere ike ghara ịnwe ígwè ọrụ ígwè na-ejegharị n'okporo ámá anyị n'Africa site n'afọ 2040, mana anyị ga-enwe ígwè ọrụ igwe na-enweghị ike ịma ya. O kwere omume na a ga-enwe ụgbọala ụgbọala "robot" n'ọdụ ụgbọ ala n'okporo ámá anyị.  
Anyị nwere ike ịnwe ígwè arụmọrụ microscopic na anya elekere anyị nke na-enyere anyị aka ịse foto - anyị agaghị enwe ma ọ bụ jide igwe ma ọ bụ igwefoto anyị iji me n'kaa (mana olee otu anyị ga-esi were mee selfies ??)
Ụmụ obere ígwè a na-akpọ drones ga - efe efe na - eziga akwụkwọ, nchịkọta na ihe dị iche iche, nwere ike iwepu ụfọdụ òtù na - azụ ahịa 
n'ọrụ ha ma belata
ụgbọ ala dị na okporo
ụzọ n'okporo ámá anyị! N'ihe dị ka afọ 2085, ònye mara ihe ígwè ọrụ ugbo ga na eme?

English: The morning sun creeps over the horizon and peeps through the leaves, waking Senzo.Gogo’s rooster shakes his wings, stretches his neck and crows. Koek-a-loek-a-loo!
Senzo can crow too.Koek-a-loek-a-loo!Can you?
The sun is bright and warm. Senzo is ready for school. He takes Gogo’s hand.The road is busy. Taxis zip past and toot their horns.Beep-beep! Beep-beep!
Senzo can toot too.Beep-beep! Beep-beep! Can you?
The sun is high in the sky. School is over and Senzo’s friends play on the grass.They stretch out their arms and run down the hill.Weeeeeee! Weeeee!
Senzo can run too.Weeeeeee! Weeeee!Can you?
The sun is low on the horizon, the sky is full of colour.The long day is nearly over and supper is finished.
Gogo and Mama wash the dishes.Splish-splash!Splish-splash!
Senzo can wash dishes too.Splish-splash! Splish-splash!Can you?

The sun is dipping under the horizon, casting long shadows. Senzo is washed and full and tired. “It’s time to sleep,” says Mama.She holds Senzo close and rocks. She hushes him.Shhhhhhhhh, shhhhhhhhhh.
Senzo can hush too.Shhhhhhhhh,shhhhhhhhh.Can you?
The sun has done her work for the day and she’s going to sleep.She pulls a blanket of darkness over herself to keep warm.The sun dreams.
Senzo can dream too. Can you?

English: When we go walking and the road is long, we’ll walk together singing a song.
I am with you and you are with me. A journey is fun with our family.
I’ll keep you cosy like a mother hen. She keeps her chicks warm under her wing.
If the rain starts to fall down from the sky, like that good hat I’ll keep your face dry.
If storm clouds get angry and grumble and moan, be brave, why cry? You’re not alone.
We’re walking together so we never get bored. Look up! Look around! See where we’ve explored!
If you see something that’s funny to see, I don’t want to miss it. Please share it with me!
If your feet start to hurt from the distance we’ve passed, don’t worry, we’ve made it! Here’s the clinic at last.
We all need to check our throat, lungs and ears. Get strong as you grow, it’s no reason for tears.
Do you think it’s scary? Here, hold my hand. She’ll check your blood pressure with this clever armband.
They give us our medicine, tell us what we should know, to keep us all healthy. Now back home we go.
It’s okay to be tired, there’s so much we’ve seen. Now it’s your bedtime. Sleep well and sweet dreams.

English: Fati was a little girlwho ran like the wind, who loved to laugh,and who always tried hard to do as she was told.
One day, Fati went on a bicycle with her father to the farm to pull some weeds.
Soon, Fati was tired. Fati said, “Father, I am hot and tired. May I sit under the mango tree? Father said, “Yes Fati, you may sit there. But, please, do not climb any trees today.”
Fati sat under the mango tree. Fati looked up. She saw one... two... three ripe mangoes!

Fati looked over at her father. He was busy and not looking her way. Quietly, Fati started to climb the mango tree.Fati thought, “I will sit on the nice, big branch. It is a good place to rest and to eat plenty of ripe mangoes.” So she sat and ate.
After she ate the mangoes, Fati climbed down... Only to see another tree.And this tree had something brown dripping down its bark.

It was honey! Fati lo-o-o-ved honey. But she did not love bees. Fati looked up and saw one little bee.Fati thought, “There is only one little bee. He will not hurt me if I climb the tree and look for honey.”
Fati looked at her father. He was not looking her way.So Fati climbed up to the top of the tree and took the honey from a deep hole.
Fati thought, “I will sit on this nice, big branch. It is a good place to rest and to eat plenty of sweet honey.” So she sat and ate.
After she ate the honey, Fati Climbed down the tree. Then she saw the bees.So many of them!BZZZ! BZZZ! BZZZ!She ran away from the bees.
Fati ran to her father.Fati was huffing and Fati was puffing.Father said, ”Fati, where have you been?” Fati did not want to say where she had been.
So, she said, “ Look, Father, I have a mango. Would you like to eat it?”Father said, “No, thank you, Fati. We must go home now. It's about to rain.”
On the way home, Fati sat behind her father on the bicycle. It started to rain.
Father went too fast on the bicycle. The bicycle went off the path. CRASH!!
The bicycle fell on Fati’s leg.
At home, mother and grandmother asked about the day at the farm."Fati climbed a tree" said father."Father went too fast on the bicycle and it fell on my leg" said Fati.
"Oh poor, poor Fati" said mother. "Poor, poor Fati," said grandmother. We must take care of your leg."And they did. And that was the end of that.

Fati wee nọrọ n'okpuru osisi mango.Fati lere anya.Ọ hụrụ mango otu ... abụọ ... atọ chara acha dị njikere iri!

English:
When I woke up in the morning, the sun was
shining again. I looked around me, wondering where I was. And then I
remembered. I was a baby sea turtle - an olive ridley - in the middle of a big
blue world, which I had heard someone call the ocean. There was blue and green
water in every direction, and the sunlight was playing games with the clouds. I
tucked my flippers beneath my body and floated for a while, letting the current
carry me.
I did not know where I was. But that does not
matter when the sun is shining, and your stomach is full.
The sun warmed me, and filled me with new energy.

Just as I was beginning to think that I would love to spend the rest of my life here, a school of fish went by. Chasing them was a really big fish. I could tell he was a really hungry fish too. When he saw me, his eyes lit up. “Mmmmm,” he seemed to be thinking, “baby turtle soup!” 
Moments later, I was swimming as fast as I could,
with those big teeth snapping at my little hind flippers.
Just when I was beginning to tire, I saw a
seaweed raft. A seaweed raft is just that, a floating mass of seaweed and
driftwood that travels around the ocean, carried along by the current. On and
in the raft are the Drifters, all the sea’s little and not-so-little creatures
that float around the ocean, waiting for something to happen. Gratefully, I
slipped into the raft. I would not leave this safe haven for many, many years.

Being on the raft was like going on a world cruise. I enjoyed it very much, but as I grew up, I decided it was time to explore the big wide world outside the raft.

I had heard
wonderful things about a place called the Reef where a lot of other turtles
lived. Everyone said the Reef
was the fairyland of the ocean. They
said it was full of beautiful, brightly-coloured creatures, both harmless ones
like the clown fish and poisonous ones like the scorpion fish. I wondered how I
would find it.

All
of a sudden, it became very dark. A huge shadow covered me. Frightened, I
looked up, only to see the biggest turtle I had ever seen. His back was soft
and leathery. I stared. A turtle with a soft back? All the ones I know have
very hard backs.

The big turtle caught me staring. “Surprised?” he grunted pleasantly. “You shouldn’t be. I’m a leatherback turtle.”

“Good name, Sir,” I mumbled. 


“Where
are you going, Sir?” I continued. “To the Reef to live with the other turtles?”
“Ah,”
sighed the leatherback. “I wish I had that luxury. But no, I am too busy
searching for jellyfish. They are all I eat.”
“Where
do you find them?” I asked.

“Out in the deep, deep, sea,” said the
leatherback. “Sometimes I have to dive more than a 1000 feet to reach them. And
sometimes I go all the way to Canada, where the water gets very cold. No other
reptile could survive in such cold waters.”“If
it isn’t too rude, Sir,” I said quietly, “can I ask how much you weigh?”
“Nearly
600 kilograms, little one,” replied the leatherback, looking amused. “And I’m
proud of all of it, including the fat. For it’s the fat that helps me get
through the long migrations. Well, I have to be off now...”

“Of
course, Sir,” I said. “But before you go, could you tell me where I might find
the Reef?”
“That
way,” said the leatherback, pointing with a flipper as he swam off.
“Thank you,
Sir, and happy hunting!” I called out as I swam towards the reef.

It was on the Reef that I met old Green Turtle. 

My friend Hawksbill, whose mouth is curved like a hawk’s beak, told me old Green was nearly 50 years old. “My! That’s old!” I said.
“How come she looks so young?” “Well,” said Hawksbill, “Green Turtle eats only
sea grass and algae, so it took her nearly 30 years to become an adult. You and
I will be adults by the time we are ten.”

“Do you know,” he
continued, “that when she wants to nest, she migrates to islands in the middle
of the ocean? Clear blue lagoons, white sand, they’re beautiful...”“Have you been there?” I
asked.“Oh yes, sometimes you
have to crawl over the coral to get to the beach,” said Hawksbill.

I shuddered. I would hate to crawl over sharp coral. Soft sand is what I like under my soft belly.“You won’t have to do it, don’t worry,” another ridley told me. “We only nest on soft beaches, like the ones on the coasts of Mexico, Costa Rica, and India. But you’ll see for yourself, when it’s time...”
“How will I know it’s time?” I asked eagerly as she swam away.“You will, trust me,” was all she would say.

I spent some happy years
on the Reef, meeting many of my turtle cousins. Apart from green turtles and
hawksbills, I met loggerhead turtles - the ones with the really big heads - and
plenty of other ridleys like me.
And then one day, just
like that, I was all grown up, and it was time to go. How did I know it was
time? I don’t know. Something deep inside me told me so. I knew I had
to swim north with all the other ridleys, all along
the eastern coast of India until we reached Orissa, and lay my eggs on the soft
beaches there. The little compass in my head would tell me how to get there.

“It’s only about 2000 kilometers,” sniffed a loggerhead as he swam off in a different direction. Show off! Just because loggerheads like him sometimes swim almost 15000 kilometres to lay their eggs (from California, all the way across the Pacific Ocean to Japan)! I ignored him, and continued gorging on flying fish, my favourite food.The big journey began. The water around me was full of other ridleys like me, swimming powerfully.

It wasn’t an easy journey.  Along the way, there
were many dangers. 




















Though I was now bigger
than most of the fish, there were still sharks that could catch us.

But
the sharks were not as dangerous as the many fishing nets that we had to swim
past.
I swam as
carefully as I could, avoiding all the nets, especially the terrible trawl
nets. I managed to escape them all, but some of my friends weren’t so lucky.
Finally, I reached the
beach of Gahirmatha, the place where more ridleys nested than anywhere else in
the Indian Ocean. It was time to lay my first nest.

We always nest at night.
I waited until the tide was a little high, so that I wouldn’t have that far to
crawl on the beach. I came in with the surf, and felt land under me for the
first time since my birth. 




















It felt very strange at
first. Slowly, I dragged myself up the beach to find a dry spot.

Once I had moved past the high-tide line, the sand became very dry and flew all around me as I dragged myself forward with my front flippers.  It is very difficult to move on land. I paused to take a breath and looked up. The beach was long and dark.

Behind the beach was a huge dune and some bushes. I had heard there was a
large forest behind this beach called Bhitarkanika which was full of saltwater
crocodiles, king cobras and all kinds of other animals.

Then, suddenly, I saw another animal on the beach. It had four legs and it
was digging up a turtle nest. I went back into the water as fast as I could.
Later that night, I crawled up again, and went up the beach into the Ipomea
creepers.
At
my chosen spot on the beach, I cleared away the dry sand, and made a big pit
with my hind flippers. I am very fussy about how exactly I do this. I always
put one flipper in after the other, scoop up some sand and throw it out.

About
two feet deep and shaped like a flask, with a narrow neck leading into a deep cavity, it was a beauty. I then began laying my eggs. 1, 2,
3,..., 44, 45,..., 99, 100 and then I was done.

I covered my precious eggs carefully with sand, and thumped it down with my
body. Finally I threw some sand around to make sure that no one would find my
nest.




Quickly,
quickly, I crawled back into the sea where I felt much safer.

Two weeks later, I was getting ready to nest
again. We usually make enough eggs to lay two or three nests during a season.
My common sense told me that it would be a good idea to nest again where I had
the previous time. It seemed like a good, safe place.
That
night, as I was waiting in the shallow water for the tide to be right, I
noticed a slight change in the wind. It was stronger and blowing from a
different direction. Suddenly I realised that there were hundreds, no,
thousands, of other turtles all waiting to nest. I knew a lot of other ridleys
were also swimming around in the Gahirmatha waters waiting to nest, but I had
never seen so many together.

About
two feet deep and shaped like a flask, with a narrow neck leading into a deep cavity, it was a beauty. I then began laying my eggs. 1, 2,
3,..., 44, 45,..., 99, 100 and then I was done.

I covered my precious eggs carefully with sand, and thumped it down with my
body. Finally I threw some sand around to make sure that no one would find my
nest.




Quickly,
quickly, I crawled back into the sea where I felt much safer.

And
then, we were all rushing up the beach together. The beach was already full.
There were thousands of other ridleys, sand was flying in the air, we were all
bumping into each other. Finally, I managed to find a clear spot, and dig a
nest for myself. The turtle next to me was in such a hurry, she started to lay
her eggs even before she could finish digging her nest. I was shocked, we
turtles never do that.

“It’s an arribada*, lady,” she said, “we all get a little crazy during this time.”
Nobody really knows why we do this. But it works
for us, because millions of hatchlings hatch at the same time. That way, most
of the little ones escape being caught by birds, crabs and jackals. These days,
of course, we have humans to worry about as well.* During an arribada - which means ‘arrival’ in Spanish - thousands of olive ridleys come ashore in a frenzy to nest. Scientists still aren’t sure why they do this.

Finally,
it is time to leave and return to my feeding ground. I will spend a year or two
there, eating and building up the energy for another visit to Gahirmatha. Green
Turtle, on the other hand, sometimes needs to eat for five or six years before
she has the energy to make her next journey to nest.
As I leave, I think of the little ones I have
left behind. For 50 to 60 days, the eggs will remain under the sand, warmed by
the sun. And then one day, they will hatch, breaking open their shells with the
tips of their snouts. They will huddle together, over a hundred hatchlings
under the sand, waiting for the sun to set and the sand to cool. Then, in the
darkness, when it is safe, they will come out, all at once. They will see the
moonlight bouncing off the sea, and know which way to go. Hopefully they will
be no streetlights to make them go in the wrong direction.

They
will swim against the waves and dive under the oncoming breakers.

Oh, there
will be big fish and small fish out to get them, and seagulls and eagles, but
some will get away. Out into the open sea where they will find their own little
seaweed rafts, their floating homes for many years. Then they will grow up, and
perhaps they will come to my feeding ground. Perhaps we will meet, though of
course I will not know them.
Still,
I am happy knowing that they are out there somewhere, and that someday they
will return like me to this very beach to lay their own eggs, and start the
whole wonderful circle of life all over again.

A MESSAGE FROM THE
OLIVE RIDLEY TO YOU
Sea turtles are in danger worldwide, for many reasons. Some species of
turtles are killed for their meat, which is used to make turtle soup. The shell
of the hawksbill turtle is used to make tortoiseshell products like eyeglass
frames and hair accessories. Many turtle eggs and hatchlings are eaten by
predators like dogs and crows. But the biggest
danger comes from fishing. Many sea turtles get accidentally caught in a
variety of fishing nets, drown, and die. In India, there are many conservation groups that are trying to save sea turtles. Each coastal state has one or more such groups.

What can YOU do to protect sea turtles?If you live near a beach where turtles come to nest:• Help keep the beach clean so that baby and mother turtles do not get hurt.•

Educate the adults in your locality about how streetlights and other lights near the beach can be harmful to turtle hatchlings – once they hatch, hatchlings figure out where the sea is by looking for the reflection of moonlight on water, so if there are other bright lights in the area, they can get confused and wander off in the wrong direction, and into danger.• Find out if your state has a local sea turtle conservation group and see if you can join them. If you don’t live near a beach:Read more and more about sea turtles and talk to everyone you know about the dangers they are facing. Spreading awareness is a BIG part of conservation.
Igbo:
Mgbe m tetara na ụtụtụ, anyanwụ na-enwu ọzọ. M lere m anya, na-eche ebe m nọ. Ma echetara. Abụ m obere mbe mmiri - olive ridley - n'etiti etiti nnukwu ụwa anụnụ anụnụ, nke m nụrụ ka mmadụ na-akpọ oké osimiri ahụ. E nwere mmiri na-acha anụnụ anụnụ na akwụkwọ ndụ akwụkwọ ndụ, na ìhè anyanwụ na-egwu egwuregwu na igwe ojii. Akwụsịrị m aka m n'okpuru ahụ m ma tụgharịa obere, na-ekwe ka mmiri na-ebu m na'ga.
Amaghị m ebe m nọ. Ma nke ahụ adịghị mkpa mgbe anyanwụ na-enwu, afọ'm jupụtara n'ọṅụ.


Anyanwụ na-eme m obi ụtọ ma jupụta m n'ike ọhụrụ

Dịka m na-amalite iche na m ga-enwe mmasị ibi oge fọdụrụ ná ndụ m ebe a, otu ìgwè azụ gafere. Nnukwu azụ buru ibu na-achụ ha. Enwere m ike ịsị na ọ bụ azụ agụ na agụụ n'ezie. Mgbe ọ hụrụ m, anya ya gbanwere . "Mmmmm," o yiri ka ọ na-eche echiche, sị, "Nri nwa mbe mmiri!"

Ozugbo m hụrụ onwe m, ana m agba mmiri ngwa ngwa ka m nwere ike, ya na nnukwu ezé na-adọta na obere azụ m.
Mgbe m malitere ịda mbà, ahụrụ m otu ugbo eji ahịhịa dị n'oké osimiri mee. Ugbo nke a sitere na ata di n'ime oke osimiri na osisi nke na-agaghari n'osimiri.
Na na ụgbọ mmiri ahụ eme site na ahịhịa ndị dị n'oké osimiri na osisi ndị na-ese n'elu oké osimiri bụ obere ihe ndị dị ntakịrị na oke osimiri ndị na-adịghị anwụ anwụ na-agagharị n'elu oké osimiri, na-echere ihe ga-eme. Eji m obi ụtọ, banye  n'ugbo ahụ

. Agaghị m ahapụ ebe nchekwa a ruo ọtụtụ afọ.
Ịnọ n'ụgbọ mmiri dịka ịga na njem ụgbọ mmiri. Ọ masịrị m nke ukwuu, ma ka m na-etolite, ekpebiri m na ọ bụ oge iji chọpụta nnukwu mbara ụwa n'èzí ụgbọ mmiri ahụ

Anụrụ m ihe ndị magburu onwe ya banyere ebe a na-akpọ Ọdụ Reef ebe

ọtụtụ mbe mmiri ntụrụndụ ndị ọzọ bi. Onye ọ bụla kwuru na Reef bụ ebe mara mma

nke oké na osimiri. Ha kwuru na ọ jupụtara n'ịma mma,

ihe na-acha uhie uhie, ma ndị na-adịghị emerụ ahụ dị ka azụ na-egbuke egbuke

na nke dị ka azụ akpị.

M na-eche otú m ga-esi chọta ya

Na mberede, ọ ghọrọ ọchịchịrị. Nnukwu onyinyo kpuchiri m. O juru m anya, m lere anya, ma hụ nnukwu mbe mmiri m hụtụrụla. Azụ ya dị nro dị ka akpụkpọ anụ. M lere anya. Mbe mmiri nwere azụ di otụa? Mbe mmiri niile m maara nwere ezigbo azụ.Nnukwu mbe mmiri jidere m ka na-ene anya. "
"I kwesịghị kaỌ tụụ gi egwu. Abụ m mbe mmiri akpụkpọ anụ. "

"Aha ọma, Nnukwu mbe mmiri," M na-atụgharị uche. M gara n'ihu. "Ebee ka ị na-aga, Nnukwu mbe mmiri?" "Ị na-aga Reef ka gi na nduru mbe mmiri ndị ọzọ biri?""Ah," sụrụ akpụkpọ anụ. "Asikwa na n'ga  eme nke'a. Ma ee, m na-arụsi ọrụ ike na-achọ jellyfish. Ha bụ nanị ihe m na-eri. ""Ebee ka ịchọta ha?" Ka m jụrụ.

"N'ime ime ime, miri, oké osimiri," ka Nnukwu mbe mmiri akpụkpọ anụ ahụ kwuru. "Mgbe ụfọdụ, m ga-adaba karịa otu puku ụkwụ iji ruo ha. Mgbe ụfọdụ, ana m aga Canada, ebe mmiri dị oyi. Ọ dịghị ihe ọ bụla ọzọ nwere ike ịdị ndụ n'ime mmiri oyi dị otú ahụ. ""Ọ bụrụ na ọ bụghị okwu mkparị, Nnnukwu mbe mmiri," M gwara ya na nwayọ, "enwere m ike ịjụ gị oke arọ idi?""Ị nwere ike ikwu n'andi narị kilogram isii, obere mbe mmiri," ka Nnukwu mbe mmiri akpụkpọ anụ kwuru. "Ana m enwekwa obi ụtọ maka ya, gụnyere abụba. N'ihi na ọ bụ abụba nke na-enyere m aka na ogologo njem. M ga-apụ ugbu a ... "

"N'ezie, Nnukwu mbe mmiri," ka m kwuru. "Ma tupu ị gawa, ị nwere ike ịgwa m ebe m nwere ike ịhụ Reef?""N'ụzọ dị otú a," ka Nnukwu mbe mmiri akpụkpọ anụ ahụ na-ekwu, na-atụ aka na na-agbapụ kwa."Ana m ekele gị, Nnukwu mbe mmiri, ịchụ nta na-obi ụtọ!" M kpọrọ mkpu ka m na-egwu mmiri gaa n'ọdụ ụgbọ mmiri.

Ọ bụ na Reef ka' m zutere agadi mbe mmiri aha ya bụ Green. Enyi m Hawksbill, onye ọnụ ya dị ka nke nnụnụ, gwara m na Green agbala afọ iri ise . "Eziokwu?  
Ọ

bụ agadi! "M kwuru. "Olee otú ọ si dị ka onye ka'na na-eto eto?" 


"Hmmm" ka Hawksbill kwuru, "Mbe mmiri Green na-eri nanị ahịhịa ndụ na algae na oké osimiri, n'ihi ya, o were afọ iri atọ ịghọ okenye. Mụ na gị ga-abụ ndị okenye mgbe anyị dị afọ iri.

"Ị maara," ka ọ gara n'ihu, "na mgbe ọ chọrọ ịmụ ụmụ, ọ na-akwaga n'ala dị n'etiti oké osimiri? Ebe ahụ nwere ọdọ mmiri na-acha anụnụ anụnụ, ájá ọcha, ha mara mma ... ""Ị gara ebe ahụ?" Ka m jụrụ."Ee ee, mgbe ụfọdụ, ị ghaghị ịgafw coral iji banye n'ụsọ osimiri," ka Hawksbil kwuru

M na-ama jijiji na egwu. Agaghị m achọ ịga na coral dị nkọ. Aja nro bu ihe na-acho m maka okpuru afo'm di nro."Ị gaghị aga ya, echegbula onwe gị," ka otu mbe mmiri ọzọ gwara m. "Anyị na-aga ụmụ nwa ọhụrụ na ọdọ mmiri dị nro, dị ka ndị dị n'ugwu Mexico, Costa Rica, na India. Ma ị ga eji anya ahụ  onwe gị, mgbe ọ bụ oge nkea'a... "
"Olee otu m ga-esi mara na ọ bụ oge ahụ?" Ajụrụ m ya n'obi ọkụ ka ọ na ga-efe ngwa ngwa."Ị ga a'ma, tụkwasị m obi," ka ọ kwuru.

Enwere m obi ụtọ na Reef, na-ezute ọtụtụ n'ime ụmụ nwanne m. E wezụga mbe mmiri Green na mbe mmiri Hawksbills, ezutere m na ntụrụndụ mbe mmiri Loggerhead - ndị nwere nnukwu isi - na ọtụtụ mbe mmriri Ridleys ndị ọzọ dị ka m.Ma n'otu ụbọchị, dị ka nke a, emeela m agadi, ọ bụ oge eji aga. Kedu ka m si mara na ọ bụ oge? Amaghị m. Ihe dị n'ime m gwara m otú ahụ. Amaara m na m ga-egwu mmiri n'ebe ugwu na ndị ọzọ Ridleys, n'akụkụ ọwụwa anyanwụ nke India ruo mgbe anyị ruru Orissa, ma debe akwa m n'osimiri ndị dị nro n'ebe ahụ. Obere ihe di na isi'm ga-agwa m otu esi aga ebe ahụ.

"Ọ bụ nanị ihe dị ka puku kilomita abụọ," ka Loggerhead kwuru ka ọ na-agbapụ n'ụzọ dị iche. Gosipụ! Naanị n'ihi na Loggerheads dị ka ya mgbe ụfọdụ na-egwu mmiri iri na ise kilomita iji dọọ akwa ha n (site na California, n'ụzọ nile gafere Pacific Ocean na Japan)! Echefuru m ya, ma nọgide na-eri azụ na-efe efe, nri m kacha amasị m.Nnukwu njem ahụ malitere.Mmiri gbara m gburugburu jupụtara na Ridleys ndị ọzọ dị ka m, naegwu mmiri n'ike n'ike.
Ọ bụghị njem dị mfe. N'ọnọdụ ahụ, e nwere ọtụtụ ihe ize ndụ. Ọ bụ ezie na m bu nnukwu mbe mmiri  ugbu a karịa ọtụtụ n'ime azụ ahụ, a ka nwere nnukwu azụ a na-akpọ shark nwere ike ijide anyị.

E nwere ihe ize ndụ ndị ọzọ dị ka ọtụtụ ụgbụ azụ ndị anyị na-egwu mmiri n'agafe.Eji m nlezianya na-egwu mmiri, na-ezere ụgbụ niile, karịsịa ndị na-egwupụta ụgbụ. Enwere m ike ịgbanahụ ha niile, ma ụfọdụ ndị enyi m aenwehị ike.N'ikpeazụ, abịarutere m n'akụkụ osimiri nke Gahirmatha, bụ ebe ndị Ridleys ọzọ dị ka m na- edesa akwa ha karịa ebe ọ bụla ọzọ dị n'Oké Osimiri India.Oge eruola ka m debe akwa nkem.

Anyị na-etinye akwa mgbe abalị. Echere m ruo mgbe mmiri ahụ dị elu, nke mere na agaghị m a'gata aka nweta ebe ahụ n'ụsọ oké osimiri. Echeere m ma banye n'ime mmiri mgbe o dị elu, ma rute ala, nke bụ oge mbụ ahụ meturu ala.

Ozugbo m gafeworo n'ugwu dị elu, ájá 
ghọrọ ihe dị ka
 nkụma gbaa m gburugburu ka m na-adọta onwe m n'aga n'ihu. O siri ike ije ije na ala dị ka mbe mmiri. Echere m ka m were ume ma lee anya n'elu.Aala n'akụkụ oké osimiri ahụ dị ogologo gbaa ọchịchịrị.

N'akụkụ osimiri ahụ bụ nnukwu ugwu ájá ájá na ụfọdụ ahịhịa. Anụrụ m na e nwere oké ọhịa nke dị n'azụ osimiri a nke a na-akpọ Bhitarkanika, nke jupụtara na aguiyi, nnukwu agwo na ụdị anụmanụ ndị ọzọ nile. Mgbe ahụ, na mberede, ahụrụ m anụmanụ ọzọ dị n'ụsọ osimiri. O nwere ụkwụ anọ na ọ na-egwu olulu na acho ebe mbe mmmiri an eyi akwa. M laghachiri mmiri ngwa ngwa ka m nwere ike.
N'abalị mgbe e mesịrị, m wee pụta ọzọ


N'ebe m họọrọ n'elu osimiri, m na-ekpochapụ ájá ájá, ma mee nnukwu olulu na ndị na-agba m. Ana m akpachara anya banyere otu m si eme nke a

Emere m ohere dị omimi na n'obosara na ime ala ma warara na elu. ọ mara ezigbo mma. Amalitere m itinye akwa m.Otu, abụọ, atọ, ..., iri anọ na anọ, iri ise, ..., iri itoolu na itoolu, otu narị, mgbe ahụ imechala m.Ejiri m ájá kpuchie akawa m ọla m dị oké ọnụ ahịa, ma kpoo ya na ahụ m. N'ikpeazụ, m tụbara ájá ụfọdụ gburugburu iji jide n'aka na ọ dịghị onye ga-achọta akwụ m.Ngwa ngwa, ngwa ngwa, abanyeghachiri m n'ime oké osimiri ebe m nwere oke nchebe.

Mgbe Izu abụọ gasịrị, ana m edozi akwụ ọzọ. Anyị na-emekarị 
akwụ zuru ezu abụọ ma ọ bụ atọ n'oge
ahụ. Uche m gwara m naọ ga-abụ ezigbo echiche ka'm me akwụ ọzọ ebe m nmere na oge gara aga. O yiri ka ebe dị mma, nke dị ezigbo nchekwebe.  N'abalị ahụ, ka m na-eche ka mmiri ahụ dị mma, achọpụtara m obere mgbanwe na ifufe. O siri ike ma na-afụ ọkụ site na ntụziaka dị iche. Na mberede, achọpụtara m na e nwere ọtụtụ narị, ọ dịghị, ọtụtụ puku mmadụ, nbe mmiri ndị ọzọ na-echere ime akwu. Amaara m na ọtụtụ Ridleys ndị ọzọ na-asọgharịkwa na mmiri Gahirmatha na-echere ka ha nwee akwụ, ma amaghị m na anyi di ọtụtụ na ọnụ.

Mgbe ahụkwa, anyị niile na-agbago ngwa ngwa n'akụkụ osimiri. Oké osimiri ahụ jupụtara ugbu a. E nwere ọtụtụ puku Ridleys ndị ọzọ, ájá na-efegharị n'elu, anyị niile na-adaba onwe anyị.N'ikpeazụ, achọrọ m ịchọta ntụpọ doro anya, gwuru onwe m akwụ. Nwanyị dị n'akụkụ m nọ na-eme ọsọ ọsọ, ọ malitere ịba akwa ya ọbụna tupu ya enwee ike igwu ala ya.Nke a ezighi ezi! E kwesịghị ime otú ahụ!

"Ọ bụ Arribada *, nwanyị," ka o kwuru, "anyị nile na-aghọ ndị nzuzu n'oge a."Ọ dịghị onye maara ihe mere anyị ji eme nke a. Ma, ọ na-arụ ọrụ maka anyị, n'ihi na ọtụtụ nde ndị na-amị ihe na-emepụta n'otu oge ahụ. N'ụzọ dị otú a, ọtụtụ n'ime obere mbe mmiri na-agbanahụ  nnụnụ, na nkịta ọhịa ijide ha. N'ezie, n'ụbọchị ndị a, anyị kwesịrị ichegbu onwe anyị banyere ụmụ mmadụ.* N'oge Arribada - nke pụtara 'ịbịarute' na Spanish - ọtụtụ puku Ridleys olive na erute n'ụsọ oké osimiri iji mee akwụ. Ndị ọkà mmụta sayensị amabeghị ihe mere ha ji eme nke a.

N'ikpeazụ, ọ bụ oge ịhapụ ma laghachi n'ala nri m. Aga m etinye otu afọ ma ọ bụ abụọ n'ebe ahụ, iri nri na iwuli ume iji laghachi na Gahirmatha. N'aka nke ọzọ, mbe mmiri Green, mgbe ụfọdụ, na-eri nri afọ ise ma ọ bụ afọ isii tupu ya enwee ume iji mee ya njem ọzọ ime akwu.
Ka m na-apụ, echere m banyere ụmụaka ndị m hapụ. Ruo ụbọchị iri ise na iri isii, akwa ahụ ga-anọgide n'okpuru ájá, anyanwụ na-enwu. Ma otu ụbọchị, ha ga-egbu ya, meghe oghere ha. Ha ga-agbakọta ọnụ, ihe karịrị otu narị nwa mbe mmiri n'okpuru ájá, na-eche ka anyanwụ daa na ka ájá jụkwa oyi.Mgbe ahụ, n'ọchịchịrị, mgbe ọ dị mma, ha ga-apụta, n'otu oge. Ha ga-ahụ ka ọnwa na-asọpụ n'oké osimiri, ma mara ụzọ nke ha ga-aga. Oga adi'nma na ha agaghị ahụ ọkụ ọzọ iji duhie ha.
Ha ga-egwu mmiri megide ebili mmiri ma daba n'okpuru mmiri ozuzo na-abịanụ.

Oh, a ga-enwe nnukwu azụ na obere azụ ga-achọ inweta ha, ugo na anụmanụ ndị ọzọ, ma ụfọdụ ga-apụ. Gaa n'oké osimiri ebe ha ga-ahụ obere obere ugbo si na ahịhịa ndị na-eto n'oké osimiri ahụ, nkea bu ụlọ ha na-ese n'elu ala ruo ọtụtụ afọ.  Mgbe ahụ, ha ga-etolite, ma eleghị anya, ha ga-abịa na ebe n'na nri nri m. Ikekwe anyị ga-ezute, ọ bụ ezie na agaghị m ama ha.
N'agbanyeghị nke ahụ, enwere m obi ụtọ n'ịmara na ha nọ n'ebe ahụ, nakwa na n'otu ụbọchị, ha ga-alaghachi dịka m gaa n'ụsọ osimiri a iji dọọ àkwá ha, ma malite usoro ndụ dị ebube ugboro ugboro.

Otu ozi si n'aka ndị mbe mmiri Olive Ridley Mbe mmiri nọ n'ihe ize ndụ n'ụwa, n'ihi ọtụtụ ihe. A na-egbu ụfọdụ mbe mmiri maka anụ ha, bụ nke a na-eji emeofe mbe mmiri.  

A na-eji azụ mbe mmiri Hawksbill mee ngwaahịa dị ka mbadamba ugogbe anya na
na ihe ndị ọzọ

Ọtụtụ ndị na-eri anụ na ụmụ mbe mmiri. Ma'na nsogbu kachasị na-abịa site na ịkụ azụ. Ọtụtụ mbe mmri ka a na-enweta na mberede n'ụgbụ azu dị iche iche, ha na-da mmiri, ma nwụọ.
N'India, e nwere ọtụtụ ndị na-echekwa nchebe na-agbalị ịchekwa nduru azụ. Ị nwere ndị dị otú ahụ na mba gị?

Kedu ihe ị ga - eme iji chekwaa mbe mmiri? Ọ bụrụ na ị bi nso n'ụsọ osimiri ebe nduru na-abata akwụ: 

• Nyere aka mee ka osimiri dị ọcha ka nne na nwa mbe mmiri ghara ịnwe ihe mgbu.
Kụzie ndị okenye nọ n'ógbè gị banyere otú ọkụ dị n'akụkụ osimiri nwere ike isi na-emerụ ndị mba mmiri ahụ. Mgbe ha pụta ha na-achọpụta ebe oké osimiri dị site na ihe ngosi nke ọnwa na mmiri, ya mere ọ bụrụ na ihe ndị ọzọ na-enwu ma obu na'gbaa ọkụ na mpaghara ahụ, ha nwere ike inwe mgbagwoju anya ma kpafuo, banye n'ime ihe ize ndụ.
• Chọpụta ma ọ bụrụ na obodo gị nwere otụ ndị na-ele ma hụ maka mbe mmiri ị nwere ike isonyere ha. 
Ma ọ bụrụ na ịnọghị nso 
n'akụkụ osimiri: Gụkwuo banyere mbe mmiri ma gwa onye ọ bụla ị maara banyere ihe ize ndụ ndị na-eche ha na ihu. Ịgbasa mgbasa ozi bụ nnukwu akụkụ nke nchekwa mbe mmiri

English: I have a friend. She lives in my house.
When I am happy, so is she.
When I cry, she cries too.
But I cannot hear her voice. My friend lives inside the mirror.
“Come out,” I tell her, “we will play.” She does not come out.
I am not happy. I go to sleep.
She comes out of the mirror in my sleep! And we have fun.
We play, we run, we shout and scream together.
When I talk to her, she also talks to me.
In the morning, my friend will go back into the mirror.
But I don't mind at all. We will play again in my dreams!
Igbo: Enwere m enyi. Ọ  bi n'ụlọ m.
Mgbe m nwere obi ụtọ, otú ahụ ka ọ dị kwa enyi'm
Mgbe m na-eti mkpu, ọ na-ebe kwa ákwá
Ma enweghị m ike ịnụ olu ya. Enyi m bi na ugogbe
"Bịa," ana m agwa ya, "anyị ga-egwu egwu." Ọ pụtaghị.
Enweghị m obi ụtọ. A'gam arahụ ụra.
O si na enyo pụta n'ụra m! Anyị nwere ọchị  na egwu egwu﻿.
Anyị na-egwu egwu, anyị na-agba ọsọ, ma na-eti kwa mkpu ọnụ.
Mgbe m na-agwa ya okwu, ọ na-agwa kwa'm okwu.
N'ụtụtụ, enyi m ga-alaghachi na enyo.
Ma echeghị uche maka nke'a ma ọlị. Anyị ga-egwu egwu ọzọ na nrọ m!

English: We are the oakum boys. We do everything together.
Penguins don’t fly, they swim. But we’re too young to swim. So we walk.
One day we went for a long walk.
We walked and walked. Until we saw something new.
He’s got somethingon his head!
You’re changing!
So are you!
It’s not so bad!
It’s not so cold!
But who’s going to teach us to swim? I will!
Igbo: Anyị bụ ụmụ nwoke Akum. Anyị na-ejiko aka onu eme ihe niile.
Nnụnụ mmiri  adịghị efe, ha na-egwu mmiri. Ma anyị na-eto eto igwu mmiri.
Otu ụbọchị, anyị gara ogologo njem.
Anyị na-eje ije ma na-eje ije. Ruo mgbe anyị hụrụ ihe ọhụrụ.

O nwere ihe di

n'isi ya!
Ị na-agbanwe!
Ma gi
Ọ dịghị njọ ri nne!
Ọ dighị oyi nnukwu!

Ma onye ga akụziri anyị igwu mmiri?


Aga m eme ya!

English: This is a fat king.
The fat king has a thin dog.The fat king and his thin dog go for a walk.
The dog sees a bird.The dog runs after the bird.
The king runs after the dog.
They run and run.They run and run for many days.
The king catches the dog.
Now the fat king is thin.
Now the fat king is thin.

Eze buru ibu nwere nkịta tara ahu.Eze buru ibu na nkịta ya tara ahu na-aga mkpahari
Nkịta na-ahụ nnụnụ.Nkịta na-agba ọsọ chude nnunu ahụ.
Eze na-agba ọsọ chude nkịta ahụ.

Ha na agba ọsọ na agba 
ọsọ

English:
One elephant is
going to drink water.
Two giraffes are going to drink water.

Three buffaloes
and four birds are also going to drink water.
Five antelopes and warthogs are walking to the water.
Seven zebras are running to the water.
Eight frogs and nine fish are swimming in the water.
One lion roars. He also wants to drink. Who is afraid of the lion?
One elephant is drinking water with the lion.
Igbo: Otu enyi na-aga ịṅụ mmiri.
Anu ogologo onu abuo na-aga inu mmiri.
Edi ọhịa atọ na nnụnụ anọ na-aga aṅụ mmiri.
Ele ise na - anu n'ebi na akuku mmiri na-eje  na mmiri.
Anyinya nwere akara akara asaa ji ọsọ agbaga na mmiri.
Mbara asatọ na azụ itoolu na-egwu mmiri n'ime mmiri.
Otu ọdụm na-ebigbọ. Ọ chọkwara ịṅụ mmiri. Ònye na-atụ egwu ọdụm?
Otu enyi na odum na-aṅụ mmiri  .

English:
Where is my cat?

I can't find my cat.

I can't find my cat anywhere.

Where is my cat?

Is he under the bed?

No, he's running out the room.

Where is my cat?

Is he on top of the cupboard?

No, he's on the bottom shelf.

Where is my cat?

Is he behind the couch?

No, he's outside in the yard.

Where is my cat?

Is he next to the bin?

No, he's jumping out the window.

Where is my cat?

Is he in the basket?

No, he's in the box.

Where is my cat?

Is he outside in the yard?

No, he's behind the curtain.

Where is my cat?

Here he is!

He is hiding in this cupboard!

English: Micki and her friends Lolo and Unathi were reading their favourite books. “If you help Micki clean her room, ”Prudence said, “you can all have biscuits afterwards.” “YAY!”
But they carried on and read and read and read.
Then they stopped reading and cleaned Micki’s room.
“My room is tidy now,” Micki said. “Let’s go and get biscuits.” But they could not find Prudence anywhere.
Micki, Lolo and Unathi stared at the biscuit jar on the top shelf wondering how to reach it.
So they found a chair and took turns to climb on it. But none of them could reach the biscuit jar. “My mama would say this is dangerous and we could fall and hurt ourselves,” Lolo said.
So Lolo sat on Unathi’s shoulders and stretched out his arms but could not reach the biscuit jar. “My father would say this is dangerous and we could fall and hurt ourselves,” Unathi said.

So they found a rope to throw around the biscuit jar and pull it down. But they could still not reach the biscuit jar. “My mummy would say this is dangerous and the jar could fall on us and hurt us,” Micki said.
“What are you doing?” Jonathan and Sakhi asked. “We are trying to reach the biscuit jar,” Micki said. “We can help you,” they said.
“Let’s push the table close to the shelf and climb on that instead,” Jonathan said.But still, none of them could reach the biscuit jar.
“Let’s throw a ball at the jar and knock it down so that the biscuits fall out,” Sakhi said. “Yes!” Lolo and Jonathan said. “No!” Unathi and Micki said.
Finally, Micki had an idea…And that is how, together, they reached the biscuit jar!
Igbo:
Makuo na ndị enyi ya Lota na Ugonna na-agụ akwụkwọ 
ndị
 ha kacha nwe amasị maka."Ọ bụrụ na unu nile nyere Makuo aka ma dozie ụlọ ya," ka Pauline kwuru, "unu nwere ike inwe achicha ọ bụla.""EEEEE!"
Ma ha na-aga n'ihu nagụ ma gụọ akwụkwọ.
Ha kwụsịrị ịgụ akwụkwọ mgbe ogologo oge gasịrịma hichaa ụlọ Makuo.

"Ụlọ m dị mma ugbu a," ka Makuo kwuru. "Ka anyị gaa nweta achicha."Ma na ha
ahụ ghị Pauline n'ebe ọ bụla.
Makuo, Lota na Ugonna lere anya na ite achicha ahụ dị n'elu na-eche otú ha ga-esi ruo ya.

Ya mere, ha were oche ma rigoro ya. Otu onye rịgoro, rịdata onye ọzọ rịgoro.Ma ọ dịghị onye ọ bụla n'ime ha nwere ike iru na ite achicha ahụ."Mama m ga-asị na nke a dị ize ndụ, anyị nwere ike ịda ma merụọ onwe anyị ahụ," ka Lota kwuru.
Ya mere, Lota nọ n'ubu Ugonna ma gbatịa ogwe aka ya, ma o nweghị ike iru na ite achicha ahụ."Papa m ga-ekwu na nke a dị ize ndụ na anyị nwere ike ịda ma merụọ onwe anyị ahụ," ka Ugonna kwuru.
"Gịnị ka unu na-eme?" Juachi na Somto jụrụ ka ha bata."Anyị na-agbalị ịbịaru ite achicha a," ka Makuo zaghachi."Anyị nwere ike inyere gị aka," ka ha kwuru.

"Ka anyị weta tebụl ahụ nso nso ma
na-esi na
ya na-arịgo," ka Juachi kwuru.Ma ka ọ dị, ọ dịghị onye ọ bụla n'ime ha nwere ike iru na ite 
ahụ.
"Ka anyị tụọ bọl na ite ahụ ma kụtuo ya ka achicha wee daa," ka Somto kwuru."Ee!" Lota na Juachi kwuru. "Ee e!" Ugonna na Makuo kwuru.
N'ikpeazụ, Makuo nwere echiche ọhụrụ ...Na nke ahụ bụ otu, jikọta ọnụ, ha rutere n'ebe ite achicha  ahụ!

English: Fati was a little girl who ran like the wind, who loved to laugh and who always tried hard to do as she was told.
Today was Sports Day at school. Fati played football and ran in three races.
After school, she walked home with her good friend Hawa.Hawa said, “Fati, you are a fast runner!”
Fati arrived home and found her mother in the kitchen.              She said, “Mother, good evening.”         Fati’s mother replied, “Fine evening. How are you?”
Fati said, “We had Sports Day at school, and I ran very fast. I am hot, tired and very hungry.”
Mother laughed and said, “My dear little Fati, you were born with fast legs!I will make okro soup and dinner will be ready soon.”

Mother put some palm oil in a big cooking pot and placed it on the fire.When the oil was hot, she added onions and garlic and stirred them until they were soft.She then put in pepper, tomatoes, added some water and six pieces of steamed cow meat.
Mother said, “Fati, please help me to stir the soup.”Fati said,”Yes, Mother.”
Fati stirred the soup once. She said, “This soup smells delicious.”
Fati stirred the soup twice. She said, “This soup smells very delicious.”
Fati stirred the soup three times. She said, “This soup smells very, very delicious.”
Then, Fati looked at her mother.Mother was not looking her way.            She was cutting green leaves for the soup.
Fati took one piece of meat from the pot and ate it.Fati said, “Mmm...”
Again, Fati looked at her mother.Her mother was not looking her way.She was cutting garden eggs for the soup.
Fati quickly took a second piece of meat from the pot and ate it.Fati said, “Mmm... Mmm...”
Once more, Fati looked at her mother.Her mother was not looking her way.She was cutting okro for the soup.
Fati very quickly took a third piece of meat from the pot and ate that too! Fati said, “Mmm... Mmm... Mmm...”
Soon, Mother came to the fire with the green leaves, garden eggs and okro.Fati was still holding the big wooden spoon.
Mother smiled and said, “Thank you for helping to stir the soup Fati.”    Fati did not know what to say.
Mother put the green leaves, garden eggs and okro in the soup and took the spoon from Fati.She started to stir the soup.

Mother looked into the pot. She could see the soup bubbling on the hot fire. Mother looked for the six pieces of meat in the pot.“One...two...three...,” said Mother. Mother saw three pieces of meat and no more.Mother said nothing. Fati said nothing.
When Mother served the soup, Fati did not get any meat. Fati said, “Mother, I am sorry. I will not do that again.” And she never did. And that was the end of that.

English: Lalita is the pet pig of Mini Singh the potter. Mini loves his pig and lets her do whatever she wants to do!Now pigs do all sorts of pig-headed things. And that's what Lalita does as well.
Harrumph! Harrumph!Lalita pushes stones all over the neat paths.
Harrr harrr harrr!She snorts and digs up the garden.
Grrrrr grrrrr grrrrr!Lalita tears up all the newspapers. Even the one Mini hasn’t read yet.
Phurrrr phurrrr phurrrr!She blows bubbles into her water bowl and spills water all over!
Chapaak! Jhapaak!Lalita chews up all the lilies and scares the fish in the pond.
“Lock her up,” says Mini's Aai. “Tie her up,” says Mini's Tai.“Never ever!” says Mini. “She never ever messes with my pots and jugs.”
One day, Mini comes to work bright and early. He whistles happily to Lalita. “Harrumph, harrumph,” she grunts back.
His happiness vanishes when he sees…Broken bowls, shattered jugsCracked cups, smashed teapotsEverywhere!
Mini gets angrier and angrier and angrier!
He ties Lalita up under the shady bougainvillea.
Lalita doesn’t understand why she is tied up. She whines and whimpers. She cries and sighs. But Mini is too angry to listen.
All day Mini works angrily and Lalita stays tied up. Then, Mini hears a noise.It isn’t a harrumph, it isn’t a harrr.It isn’t a grrr, it isn’t a phurrr.And it isn’t a chapaak or a jhapaak!
MEOOWWW!CRASH!MEOOOWWW!THUNK! It is a large, orange cat!It is the large, orange cat that knocked over the pots and jugs.
Mini unties Lalita.“Harrumph, harrumph,” she grunts.Lalita chases the cat. Round and round, and right out of the pottery!
Then Lalita goes right back to doing pig-headed things.Because that’s what pigs do.

Lalita na-atụgharị nkume niile n'ụzọ dị ọcha
