mapụahụ. "Anyị ahụbeghị ụgbọ mmiri nke'a," Ralu kwuru na otu aka n'a tankị ha dọtara."Ka anyị gaa," Somto kwetara.Ralu na Somto malitere ịrị ugwu ahụ. Mmiri ahụ kọrọ kwara na ebe ahụ."Ma eleghị anya, anyị ekwesịghị ịgha akwụkwọ. Nke a nwere ike ikpochakwa mmiri a, "ka somto kwuru na'mwute.

Mgbe ha rutere n'ụgbọ mmiri ahụ, Ralu na Somto ghọtara.Nke a tankị

 juru na mmiri!

Somto turu aka na obere mgbapụta na njedebe ọdọ mmiri ahụ. E nwere tankị dị n'okpuru ala ahụ, na-achịkọta mmiri ka ọ na-asọ. Otu nwoke guzoro n'akụkụ, na-eduzi ụgbọ mmiri ahụ."A ghọtara ihe omimi ugbu a," ka Ralu ji iwe kwuo. O nwetụbeghị iwe mgbe ọ gbasịrị ihe omimi.

"Ebee ka ị na-ewere mmiri anyị?" Ralu chọrọ ịma."Obodo ahụ," ka nwoke ahụ kwuru. "Ha nwere ọtụtụ mmadụ, n'ihi ya ha chọrọ mmiri ka ukwuu.""Nke ahụ adịghị mma!" Ka Somto kwuru.Nwoke ahụ ji nwayọọ nwayọọ kwuo, "Ọ bụ otú ahụ.""Enyi m bụ Onye Injinia," ka Ranj kwupụtara. "Ọ maara ihe dị mma."Nwoke ahụ chịrị ọchị. "Injinia! Ị bụ ụmụaka! "Somto ji nwayọọ kwuo, "Ee, ma amaara m na ị gaghị ewepụ mmiri anyị.""Laa n'ụlọ," ka nwoke ahụ kwuru. "Ị pụghị ịgbanwe ihe ọ bụla!"

Anyị ga-agbaji mgbapụta gị! "Ralu dara mkpu, na-agba ọsọ na mgbapụta ma jide osisi."Oho!" Ka nwoke ahụ kwuru. "Ekwesighi ka ndị injinia na-ewu ụlọ maka mmiri, ọ bụghị imebi ha?""Ee ... mba ... adighi ka nke a ..." Somto kwuru, na obi iru ala.Ma Ralu kwuru, "Abụ m onye nchọpụta! Enwere m ike ime ihe m chọrọ.
Ralu nwere ezi echiche. O jidere na mgbapụta ahụ. "Ị pụghị ịgbanwe ya ugbu a!"Somto gbagoro iji jidekwa mgbapụta ahụ."Hey!" Ka nwoke ahụ kwuru. Ugbu a iwe were ya. "N laa n'ụlọ," ka o kwuru.

Nke ahụ bụ mgbe ígwé ojii gbapụtara. Égbè eluigwe dara, àmụmà gbawara, mmiri ozuzo malitere ịda ma na wụsa. Somto malitere ịchị ọchị."Mmiri na-ezo ebe a, mmiri amalitela!" Ralu tiri mkpu."Ana m aga n'ụlọ m" ka nwoke ahụ kwuru.Mmiri wee zoo na ezo na ezo.
WOOSH, ihe ndị ahụ na-agabiga, mmiri na-agbada, na-agba ha."A chọtawo mmiri ahụ! Achọpụtawo mystery! "Ralu kwuru."WOOOOOO!" Ha were ọṅụ.

Tankị 

- Aha maka ebe mmadụ mere iji nweta mmiri. Ụdị tank nwere ike ịdị iche site na obere ọdọ mmiri.

English: Micki and her friends Lolo and Unathi were reading their favourite books. “If you help Micki clean her room, ”Prudence said, “you can all have biscuits afterwards.” “YAY!”
But they carried on and read and read and read.
Then they stopped reading and cleaned Micki’s room.
“My room is tidy now,” Micki said. “Let’s go and get biscuits.” But they could not find Prudence anywhere.
Micki, Lolo and Unathi stared at the biscuit jar on the top shelf wondering how to reach it.
So they found a chair and took turns to climb on it. But none of them could reach the biscuit jar. “My mama would say this is dangerous and we could fall and hurt ourselves,” Lolo said.
So Lolo sat on Unathi’s shoulders and stretched out his arms but could not reach the biscuit jar. “My father would say this is dangerous and we could fall and hurt ourselves,” Unathi said.

So they found a rope to throw around the biscuit jar and pull it down. But they could still not reach the biscuit jar. “My mummy would say this is dangerous and the jar could fall on us and hurt us,” Micki said.
“What are you doing?” Jonathan and Sakhi asked. “We are trying to reach the biscuit jar,” Micki said. “We can help you,” they said.
“Let’s push the table close to the shelf and climb on that instead,” Jonathan said.But still, none of them could reach the biscuit jar.
“Let’s throw a ball at the jar and knock it down so that the biscuits fall out,” Sakhi said. “Yes!” Lolo and Jonathan said. “No!” Unathi and Micki said.
Finally, Micki had an idea…And that is how, together, they reached the biscuit jar!
Igbo:
Makuo na ndị enyi ya Lota na Ugonna na-agụ akwụkwọ 
ndị
 ha kacha nwe amasị maka."Ọ bụrụ na unu nile nyere Makuo aka ma dozie ụlọ ya," ka Pauline kwuru, "unu nwere ike inwe achicha ọ bụla.""EEEEE!"
Ma ha na-aga n'ihu nagụ ma gụọ akwụkwọ.
Ha kwụsịrị ịgụ akwụkwọ mgbe ogologo oge gasịrịma hichaa ụlọ Makuo.

"Ụlọ m dị mma ugbu a," ka Makuo kwuru. "Ka anyị gaa nweta achicha."Ma na ha
ahụ ghị Pauline n'ebe ọ bụla.
Makuo, Lota na Ugonna lere anya na ite achicha ahụ dị n'elu na-eche otú ha ga-esi ruo ya.

Ya mere, ha were oche ma rigoro ya. Otu onye rịgoro, rịdata onye ọzọ rịgoro.Ma ọ dịghị onye ọ bụla n'ime ha nwere ike iru na ite achicha ahụ."Mama m ga-asị na nke a dị ize ndụ, anyị nwere ike ịda ma merụọ onwe anyị ahụ," ka Lota kwuru.
Ya mere, Lota nọ n'ubu Ugonna ma gbatịa ogwe aka ya, ma o nweghị ike iru na ite achicha ahụ."Papa m ga-ekwu na nke a dị ize ndụ na anyị nwere ike ịda ma merụọ onwe anyị ahụ," ka Ugonna kwuru.
"Gịnị ka unu na-eme?" Juachi na Somto jụrụ ka ha bata."Anyị na-agbalị ịbịaru ite achicha a," ka Makuo zaghachi."Anyị nwere ike inyere gị aka," ka ha kwuru.

"Ka anyị weta tebụl ahụ nso nso ma
na-esi na
ya na-arịgo," ka Juachi kwuru.Ma ka ọ dị, ọ dịghị onye ọ bụla n'ime ha nwere ike iru na ite 
ahụ.
"Ka anyị tụọ bọl na ite ahụ ma kụtuo ya ka achicha wee daa," ka Somto kwuru."Ee!" Lota na Juachi kwuru. "Ee e!" Ugonna na Makuo kwuru.
N'ikpeazụ, Makuo nwere echiche ọhụrụ ...Na nke ahụ bụ otu, jikọta ọnụ, ha rutere n'ebe ite achicha  ahụ!

English:
When I woke up in the morning, the sun was
shining again. I looked around me, wondering where I was. And then I
remembered. I was a baby sea turtle - an olive ridley - in the middle of a big
blue world, which I had heard someone call the ocean. There was blue and green
water in every direction, and the sunlight was playing games with the clouds. I
tucked my flippers beneath my body and floated for a while, letting the current
carry me.
I did not know where I was. But that does not
matter when the sun is shining, and your stomach is full.
The sun warmed me, and filled me with new energy.

Just as I was beginning to think that I would love to spend the rest of my life here, a school of fish went by. Chasing them was a really big fish. I could tell he was a really hungry fish too. When he saw me, his eyes lit up. “Mmmmm,” he seemed to be thinking, “baby turtle soup!” 
Moments later, I was swimming as fast as I could,
with those big teeth snapping at my little hind flippers.
Just when I was beginning to tire, I saw a
seaweed raft. A seaweed raft is just that, a floating mass of seaweed and
driftwood that travels around the ocean, carried along by the current. On and
in the raft are the Drifters, all the sea’s little and not-so-little creatures
that float around the ocean, waiting for something to happen. Gratefully, I
slipped into the raft. I would not leave this safe haven for many, many years.

Being on the raft was like going on a world cruise. I enjoyed it very much, but as I grew up, I decided it was time to explore the big wide world outside the raft.

I had heard
wonderful things about a place called the Reef where a lot of other turtles
lived. Everyone said the Reef
was the fairyland of the ocean. They
said it was full of beautiful, brightly-coloured creatures, both harmless ones
like the clown fish and poisonous ones like the scorpion fish. I wondered how I
would find it.

All
of a sudden, it became very dark. A huge shadow covered me. Frightened, I
looked up, only to see the biggest turtle I had ever seen. His back was soft
and leathery. I stared. A turtle with a soft back? All the ones I know have
very hard backs.

The big turtle caught me staring. “Surprised?” he grunted pleasantly. “You shouldn’t be. I’m a leatherback turtle.”

“Good name, Sir,” I mumbled. 


“Where
are you going, Sir?” I continued. “To the Reef to live with the other turtles?”
“Ah,”
sighed the leatherback. “I wish I had that luxury. But no, I am too busy
searching for jellyfish. They are all I eat.”
“Where
do you find them?” I asked.

“Out in the deep, deep, sea,” said the
leatherback. “Sometimes I have to dive more than a 1000 feet to reach them. And
sometimes I go all the way to Canada, where the water gets very cold. No other
reptile could survive in such cold waters.”“If
it isn’t too rude, Sir,” I said quietly, “can I ask how much you weigh?”
“Nearly
600 kilograms, little one,” replied the leatherback, looking amused. “And I’m
proud of all of it, including the fat. For it’s the fat that helps me get
through the long migrations. Well, I have to be off now...”

“Of
course, Sir,” I said. “But before you go, could you tell me where I might find
the Reef?”
“That
way,” said the leatherback, pointing with a flipper as he swam off.
“Thank you,
Sir, and happy hunting!” I called out as I swam towards the reef.

It was on the Reef that I met old Green Turtle. 

My friend Hawksbill, whose mouth is curved like a hawk’s beak, told me old Green was nearly 50 years old. “My! That’s old!” I said.
“How come she looks so young?” “Well,” said Hawksbill, “Green Turtle eats only
sea grass and algae, so it took her nearly 30 years to become an adult. You and
I will be adults by the time we are ten.”

“Do you know,” he
continued, “that when she wants to nest, she migrates to islands in the middle
of the ocean? Clear blue lagoons, white sand, they’re beautiful...”“Have you been there?” I
asked.“Oh yes, sometimes you
have to crawl over the coral to get to the beach,” said Hawksbill.

I shuddered. I would hate to crawl over sharp coral. Soft sand is what I like under my soft belly.“You won’t have to do it, don’t worry,” another ridley told me. “We only nest on soft beaches, like the ones on the coasts of Mexico, Costa Rica, and India. But you’ll see for yourself, when it’s time...”
“How will I know it’s time?” I asked eagerly as she swam away.“You will, trust me,” was all she would say.

I spent some happy years
on the Reef, meeting many of my turtle cousins. Apart from green turtles and
hawksbills, I met loggerhead turtles - the ones with the really big heads - and
plenty of other ridleys like me.
And then one day, just
like that, I was all grown up, and it was time to go. How did I know it was
time? I don’t know. Something deep inside me told me so. I knew I had
to swim north with all the other ridleys, all along
the eastern coast of India until we reached Orissa, and lay my eggs on the soft
beaches there. The little compass in my head would tell me how to get there.

“It’s only about 2000 kilometers,” sniffed a loggerhead as he swam off in a different direction. Show off! Just because loggerheads like him sometimes swim almost 15000 kilometres to lay their eggs (from California, all the way across the Pacific Ocean to Japan)! I ignored him, and continued gorging on flying fish, my favourite food.The big journey began. The water around me was full of other ridleys like me, swimming powerfully.

It wasn’t an easy journey.  Along the way, there
were many dangers. 




















Though I was now bigger
than most of the fish, there were still sharks that could catch us.

But
the sharks were not as dangerous as the many fishing nets that we had to swim
past.
I swam as
carefully as I could, avoiding all the nets, especially the terrible trawl
nets. I managed to escape them all, but some of my friends weren’t so lucky.
Finally, I reached the
beach of Gahirmatha, the place where more ridleys nested than anywhere else in
the Indian Ocean. It was time to lay my first nest.

We always nest at night.
I waited until the tide was a little high, so that I wouldn’t have that far to
crawl on the beach. I came in with the surf, and felt land under me for the
first time since my birth. 




















It felt very strange at
first. Slowly, I dragged myself up the beach to find a dry spot.

Once I had moved past the high-tide line, the sand became very dry and flew all around me as I dragged myself forward with my front flippers.  It is very difficult to move on land. I paused to take a breath and looked up. The beach was long and dark.

Behind the beach was a huge dune and some bushes. I had heard there was a
large forest behind this beach called Bhitarkanika which was full of saltwater
crocodiles, king cobras and all kinds of other animals.

Then, suddenly, I saw another animal on the beach. It had four legs and it
was digging up a turtle nest. I went back into the water as fast as I could.
Later that night, I crawled up again, and went up the beach into the Ipomea
creepers.
At
my chosen spot on the beach, I cleared away the dry sand, and made a big pit
with my hind flippers. I am very fussy about how exactly I do this. I always
put one flipper in after the other, scoop up some sand and throw it out.

About
two feet deep and shaped like a flask, with a narrow neck leading into a deep cavity, it was a beauty. I then began laying my eggs. 1, 2,
3,..., 44, 45,..., 99, 100 and then I was done.

I covered my precious eggs carefully with sand, and thumped it down with my
body. Finally I threw some sand around to make sure that no one would find my
nest.




Quickly,
quickly, I crawled back into the sea where I felt much safer.

Two weeks later, I was getting ready to nest
again. We usually make enough eggs to lay two or three nests during a season.
My common sense told me that it would be a good idea to nest again where I had
the previous time. It seemed like a good, safe place.
That
night, as I was waiting in the shallow water for the tide to be right, I
noticed a slight change in the wind. It was stronger and blowing from a
different direction. Suddenly I realised that there were hundreds, no,
thousands, of other turtles all waiting to nest. I knew a lot of other ridleys
were also swimming around in the Gahirmatha waters waiting to nest, but I had
never seen so many together.

About
two feet deep and shaped like a flask, with a narrow neck leading into a deep cavity, it was a beauty. I then began laying my eggs. 1, 2,
3,..., 44, 45,..., 99, 100 and then I was done.

I covered my precious eggs carefully with sand, and thumped it down with my
body. Finally I threw some sand around to make sure that no one would find my
nest.




Quickly,
quickly, I crawled back into the sea where I felt much safer.

And
then, we were all rushing up the beach together. The beach was already full.
There were thousands of other ridleys, sand was flying in the air, we were all
bumping into each other. Finally, I managed to find a clear spot, and dig a
nest for myself. The turtle next to me was in such a hurry, she started to lay
her eggs even before she could finish digging her nest. I was shocked, we
turtles never do that.

“It’s an arribada*, lady,” she said, “we all get a little crazy during this time.”
Nobody really knows why we do this. But it works
for us, because millions of hatchlings hatch at the same time. That way, most
of the little ones escape being caught by birds, crabs and jackals. These days,
of course, we have humans to worry about as well.* During an arribada - which means ‘arrival’ in Spanish - thousands of olive ridleys come ashore in a frenzy to nest. Scientists still aren’t sure why they do this.

Finally,
it is time to leave and return to my feeding ground. I will spend a year or two
there, eating and building up the energy for another visit to Gahirmatha. Green
Turtle, on the other hand, sometimes needs to eat for five or six years before
she has the energy to make her next journey to nest.
As I leave, I think of the little ones I have
left behind. For 50 to 60 days, the eggs will remain under the sand, warmed by
the sun. And then one day, they will hatch, breaking open their shells with the
tips of their snouts. They will huddle together, over a hundred hatchlings
under the sand, waiting for the sun to set and the sand to cool. Then, in the
darkness, when it is safe, they will come out, all at once. They will see the
moonlight bouncing off the sea, and know which way to go. Hopefully they will
be no streetlights to make them go in the wrong direction.

They
will swim against the waves and dive under the oncoming breakers.

Oh, there
will be big fish and small fish out to get them, and seagulls and eagles, but
some will get away. Out into the open sea where they will find their own little
seaweed rafts, their floating homes for many years. Then they will grow up, and
perhaps they will come to my feeding ground. Perhaps we will meet, though of
course I will not know them.
Still,
I am happy knowing that they are out there somewhere, and that someday they
will return like me to this very beach to lay their own eggs, and start the
whole wonderful circle of life all over again.

A MESSAGE FROM THE
OLIVE RIDLEY TO YOU
Sea turtles are in danger worldwide, for many reasons. Some species of
turtles are killed for their meat, which is used to make turtle soup. The shell
of the hawksbill turtle is used to make tortoiseshell products like eyeglass
frames and hair accessories. Many turtle eggs and hatchlings are eaten by
predators like dogs and crows. But the biggest
danger comes from fishing. Many sea turtles get accidentally caught in a
variety of fishing nets, drown, and die. In India, there are many conservation groups that are trying to save sea turtles. Each coastal state has one or more such groups.

What can YOU do to protect sea turtles?If you live near a beach where turtles come to nest:• Help keep the beach clean so that baby and mother turtles do not get hurt.•

Educate the adults in your locality about how streetlights and other lights near the beach can be harmful to turtle hatchlings – once they hatch, hatchlings figure out where the sea is by looking for the reflection of moonlight on water, so if there are other bright lights in the area, they can get confused and wander off in the wrong direction, and into danger.• Find out if your state has a local sea turtle conservation group and see if you can join them. If you don’t live near a beach:Read more and more about sea turtles and talk to everyone you know about the dangers they are facing. Spreading awareness is a BIG part of conservation.
Igbo:
Mgbe m tetara na ụtụtụ, anyanwụ na-enwu ọzọ. M lere m anya, na-eche ebe m nọ. Ma echetara. Abụ m obere mbe mmiri - olive ridley - n'etiti etiti nnukwu ụwa anụnụ anụnụ, nke m nụrụ ka mmadụ na-akpọ oké osimiri ahụ. E nwere mmiri na-acha anụnụ anụnụ na akwụkwọ ndụ akwụkwọ ndụ, na ìhè anyanwụ na-egwu egwuregwu na igwe ojii. Akwụsịrị m aka m n'okpuru ahụ m ma tụgharịa obere, na-ekwe ka mmiri na-ebu m na'ga.
Amaghị m ebe m nọ. Ma nke ahụ adịghị mkpa mgbe anyanwụ na-enwu, afọ'm jupụtara n'ọṅụ.


Anyanwụ na-eme m obi ụtọ ma jupụta m n'ike ọhụrụ

Dịka m na-amalite iche na m ga-enwe mmasị ibi oge fọdụrụ ná ndụ m ebe a, otu ìgwè azụ gafere. Nnukwu azụ buru ibu na-achụ ha. Enwere m ike ịsị na ọ bụ azụ agụ na agụụ n'ezie. Mgbe ọ hụrụ m, anya ya gbanwere . "Mmmmm," o yiri ka ọ na-eche echiche, sị, "Nri nwa mbe mmiri!"

Ozugbo m hụrụ onwe m, ana m agba mmiri ngwa ngwa ka m nwere ike, ya na nnukwu ezé na-adọta na obere azụ m.
Mgbe m malitere ịda mbà, ahụrụ m otu ugbo eji ahịhịa dị n'oké osimiri mee. Ugbo nke a sitere na ata di n'ime oke osimiri na osisi nke na-agaghari n'osimiri.
Na na ụgbọ mmiri ahụ eme site na ahịhịa ndị dị n'oké osimiri na osisi ndị na-ese n'elu oké osimiri bụ obere ihe ndị dị ntakịrị na oke osimiri ndị na-adịghị anwụ anwụ na-agagharị n'elu oké osimiri, na-echere ihe ga-eme. Eji m obi ụtọ, banye  n'ugbo ahụ

. Agaghị m ahapụ ebe nchekwa a ruo ọtụtụ afọ.
Ịnọ n'ụgbọ mmiri dịka ịga na njem ụgbọ mmiri. Ọ masịrị m nke ukwuu, ma ka m na-etolite, ekpebiri m na ọ bụ oge iji chọpụta nnukwu mbara ụwa n'èzí ụgbọ mmiri ahụ

Anụrụ m ihe ndị magburu onwe ya banyere ebe a na-akpọ Ọdụ Reef ebe

ọtụtụ mbe mmiri ntụrụndụ ndị ọzọ bi. Onye ọ bụla kwuru na Reef bụ ebe mara mma

nke oké na osimiri. Ha kwuru na ọ jupụtara n'ịma mma,

ihe na-acha uhie uhie, ma ndị na-adịghị emerụ ahụ dị ka azụ na-egbuke egbuke

na nke dị ka azụ akpị.

M na-eche otú m ga-esi chọta ya

Na mberede, ọ ghọrọ ọchịchịrị. Nnukwu onyinyo kpuchiri m. O juru m anya, m lere anya, ma hụ nnukwu mbe mmiri m hụtụrụla. Azụ ya dị nro dị ka akpụkpọ anụ. M lere anya. Mbe mmiri nwere azụ di otụa? Mbe mmiri niile m maara nwere ezigbo azụ.Nnukwu mbe mmiri jidere m ka na-ene anya. "
"I kwesịghị kaỌ tụụ gi egwu. Abụ m mbe mmiri akpụkpọ anụ. "

"Aha ọma, Nnukwu mbe mmiri," M na-atụgharị uche. M gara n'ihu. "Ebee ka ị na-aga, Nnukwu mbe mmiri?" "Ị na-aga Reef ka gi na nduru mbe mmiri ndị ọzọ biri?""Ah," sụrụ akpụkpọ anụ. "Asikwa na n'ga  eme nke'a. Ma ee, m na-arụsi ọrụ ike na-achọ jellyfish. Ha bụ nanị ihe m na-eri. ""Ebee ka ịchọta ha?" Ka m jụrụ.

"N'ime ime ime, miri, oké osimiri," ka Nnukwu mbe mmiri akpụkpọ anụ ahụ kwuru. "Mgbe ụfọdụ, m ga-adaba karịa otu puku ụkwụ iji ruo ha. Mgbe ụfọdụ, ana m aga Canada, ebe mmiri dị oyi. Ọ dịghị ihe ọ bụla ọzọ nwere ike ịdị ndụ n'ime mmiri oyi dị otú ahụ. ""Ọ bụrụ na ọ bụghị okwu mkparị, Nnnukwu mbe mmiri," M gwara ya na nwayọ, "enwere m ike ịjụ gị oke arọ idi?""Ị nwere ike ikwu n'andi narị kilogram isii, obere mbe mmiri," ka Nnukwu mbe mmiri akpụkpọ anụ kwuru. "Ana m enwekwa obi ụtọ maka ya, gụnyere abụba. N'ihi na ọ bụ abụba nke na-enyere m aka na ogologo njem. M ga-apụ ugbu a ... "

"N'ezie, Nnukwu mbe mmiri," ka m kwuru. "Ma tupu ị gawa, ị nwere ike ịgwa m ebe m nwere ike ịhụ Reef?""N'ụzọ dị otú a," ka Nnukwu mbe mmiri akpụkpọ anụ ahụ na-ekwu, na-atụ aka na na-agbapụ kwa."Ana m ekele gị, Nnukwu mbe mmiri, ịchụ nta na-obi ụtọ!" M kpọrọ mkpu ka m na-egwu mmiri gaa n'ọdụ ụgbọ mmiri.

Ọ bụ na Reef ka' m zutere agadi mbe mmiri aha ya bụ Green. Enyi m Hawksbill, onye ọnụ ya dị ka nke nnụnụ, gwara m na Green agbala afọ iri ise . "Eziokwu?  
Ọ

bụ agadi! "M kwuru. "Olee otú ọ si dị ka onye ka'na na-eto eto?" 


"Hmmm" ka Hawksbill kwuru, "Mbe mmiri Green na-eri nanị ahịhịa ndụ na algae na oké osimiri, n'ihi ya, o were afọ iri atọ ịghọ okenye. Mụ na gị ga-abụ ndị okenye mgbe anyị dị afọ iri.

"Ị maara," ka ọ gara n'ihu, "na mgbe ọ chọrọ ịmụ ụmụ, ọ na-akwaga n'ala dị n'etiti oké osimiri? Ebe ahụ nwere ọdọ mmiri na-acha anụnụ anụnụ, ájá ọcha, ha mara mma ... ""Ị gara ebe ahụ?" Ka m jụrụ."Ee ee, mgbe ụfọdụ, ị ghaghị ịgafw coral iji banye n'ụsọ osimiri," ka Hawksbil kwuru

M na-ama jijiji na egwu. Agaghị m achọ ịga na coral dị nkọ. Aja nro bu ihe na-acho m maka okpuru afo'm di nro."Ị gaghị aga ya, echegbula onwe gị," ka otu mbe mmiri ọzọ gwara m. "Anyị na-aga ụmụ nwa ọhụrụ na ọdọ mmiri dị nro, dị ka ndị dị n'ugwu Mexico, Costa Rica, na India. Ma ị ga eji anya ahụ  onwe gị, mgbe ọ bụ oge nkea'a... "
"Olee otu m ga-esi mara na ọ bụ oge ahụ?" Ajụrụ m ya n'obi ọkụ ka ọ na ga-efe ngwa ngwa."Ị ga a'ma, tụkwasị m obi," ka ọ kwuru.

Enwere m obi ụtọ na Reef, na-ezute ọtụtụ n'ime ụmụ nwanne m. E wezụga mbe mmiri Green na mbe mmiri Hawksbills, ezutere m na ntụrụndụ mbe mmiri Loggerhead - ndị nwere nnukwu isi - na ọtụtụ mbe mmriri Ridleys ndị ọzọ dị ka m.Ma n'otu ụbọchị, dị ka nke a, emeela m agadi, ọ bụ oge eji aga. Kedu ka m si mara na ọ bụ oge? Amaghị m. Ihe dị n'ime m gwara m otú ahụ. Amaara m na m ga-egwu mmiri n'ebe ugwu na ndị ọzọ Ridleys, n'akụkụ ọwụwa anyanwụ nke India ruo mgbe anyị ruru Orissa, ma debe akwa m n'osimiri ndị dị nro n'ebe ahụ. Obere ihe di na isi'm ga-agwa m otu esi aga ebe ahụ.

"Ọ bụ nanị ihe dị ka puku kilomita abụọ," ka Loggerhead kwuru ka ọ na-agbapụ n'ụzọ dị iche. Gosipụ! Naanị n'ihi na Loggerheads dị ka ya mgbe ụfọdụ na-egwu mmiri iri na ise kilomita iji dọọ akwa ha n (site na California, n'ụzọ nile gafere Pacific Ocean na Japan)! Echefuru m ya, ma nọgide na-eri azụ na-efe efe, nri m kacha amasị m.Nnukwu njem ahụ malitere.Mmiri gbara m gburugburu jupụtara na Ridleys ndị ọzọ dị ka m, naegwu mmiri n'ike n'ike.
Ọ bụghị njem dị mfe. N'ọnọdụ ahụ, e nwere ọtụtụ ihe ize ndụ. Ọ bụ ezie na m bu nnukwu mbe mmiri  ugbu a karịa ọtụtụ n'ime azụ ahụ, a ka nwere nnukwu azụ a na-akpọ shark nwere ike ijide anyị.

E nwere ihe ize ndụ ndị ọzọ dị ka ọtụtụ ụgbụ azụ ndị anyị na-egwu mmiri n'agafe.Eji m nlezianya na-egwu mmiri, na-ezere ụgbụ niile, karịsịa ndị na-egwupụta ụgbụ. Enwere m ike ịgbanahụ ha niile, ma ụfọdụ ndị enyi m aenwehị ike.N'ikpeazụ, abịarutere m n'akụkụ osimiri nke Gahirmatha, bụ ebe ndị Ridleys ọzọ dị ka m na- edesa akwa ha karịa ebe ọ bụla ọzọ dị n'Oké Osimiri India.Oge eruola ka m debe akwa nkem.

Anyị na-etinye akwa mgbe abalị. Echere m ruo mgbe mmiri ahụ dị elu, nke mere na agaghị m a'gata aka nweta ebe ahụ n'ụsọ oké osimiri. Echeere m ma banye n'ime mmiri mgbe o dị elu, ma rute ala, nke bụ oge mbụ ahụ meturu ala.

Ozugbo m gafeworo n'ugwu dị elu, ájá 
ghọrọ ihe dị ka
 nkụma gbaa m gburugburu ka m na-adọta onwe m n'aga n'ihu. O siri ike ije ije na ala dị ka mbe mmiri. Echere m ka m were ume ma lee anya n'elu.Aala n'akụkụ oké osimiri ahụ dị ogologo gbaa ọchịchịrị.

N'akụkụ osimiri ahụ bụ nnukwu ugwu ájá ájá na ụfọdụ ahịhịa. Anụrụ m na e nwere oké ọhịa nke dị n'azụ osimiri a nke a na-akpọ Bhitarkanika, nke jupụtara na aguiyi, nnukwu agwo na ụdị anụmanụ ndị ọzọ nile. Mgbe ahụ, na mberede, ahụrụ m anụmanụ ọzọ dị n'ụsọ osimiri. O nwere ụkwụ anọ na ọ na-egwu olulu na acho ebe mbe mmmiri an eyi akwa. M laghachiri mmiri ngwa ngwa ka m nwere ike.
N'abalị mgbe e mesịrị, m wee pụta ọzọ


N'ebe m họọrọ n'elu osimiri, m na-ekpochapụ ájá ájá, ma mee nnukwu olulu na ndị na-agba m. Ana m akpachara anya banyere otu m si eme nke a

Emere m ohere dị omimi na n'obosara na ime ala ma warara na elu. ọ mara ezigbo mma. Amalitere m itinye akwa m.Otu, abụọ, atọ, ..., iri anọ na anọ, iri ise, ..., iri itoolu na itoolu, otu narị, mgbe ahụ imechala m.Ejiri m ájá kpuchie akawa m ọla m dị oké ọnụ ahịa, ma kpoo ya na ahụ m. N'ikpeazụ, m tụbara ájá ụfọdụ gburugburu iji jide n'aka na ọ dịghị onye ga-achọta akwụ m.Ngwa ngwa, ngwa ngwa, abanyeghachiri m n'ime oké osimiri ebe m nwere oke nchebe.

Mgbe Izu abụọ gasịrị, ana m edozi akwụ ọzọ. Anyị na-emekarị 
akwụ zuru ezu abụọ ma ọ bụ atọ n'oge
ahụ. Uche m gwara m naọ ga-abụ ezigbo echiche ka'm me akwụ ọzọ ebe m nmere na oge gara aga. O yiri ka ebe dị mma, nke dị ezigbo nchekwebe.  N'abalị ahụ, ka m na-eche ka mmiri ahụ dị mma, achọpụtara m obere mgbanwe na ifufe. O siri ike ma na-afụ ọkụ site na ntụziaka dị iche. Na mberede, achọpụtara m na e nwere ọtụtụ narị, ọ dịghị, ọtụtụ puku mmadụ, nbe mmiri ndị ọzọ na-echere ime akwu. Amaara m na ọtụtụ Ridleys ndị ọzọ na-asọgharịkwa na mmiri Gahirmatha na-echere ka ha nwee akwụ, ma amaghị m na anyi di ọtụtụ na ọnụ.

Mgbe ahụkwa, anyị niile na-agbago ngwa ngwa n'akụkụ osimiri. Oké osimiri ahụ jupụtara ugbu a. E nwere ọtụtụ puku Ridleys ndị ọzọ, ájá na-efegharị n'elu, anyị niile na-adaba onwe anyị.N'ikpeazụ, achọrọ m ịchọta ntụpọ doro anya, gwuru onwe m akwụ. Nwanyị dị n'akụkụ m nọ na-eme ọsọ ọsọ, ọ malitere ịba akwa ya ọbụna tupu ya enwee ike igwu ala ya.Nke a ezighi ezi! E kwesịghị ime otú ahụ!

"Ọ bụ Arribada *, nwanyị," ka o kwuru, "anyị nile na-aghọ ndị nzuzu n'oge a."Ọ dịghị onye maara ihe mere anyị ji eme nke a. Ma, ọ na-arụ ọrụ maka anyị, n'ihi na ọtụtụ nde ndị na-amị ihe na-emepụta n'otu oge ahụ. N'ụzọ dị otú a, ọtụtụ n'ime obere mbe mmiri na-agbanahụ  nnụnụ, na nkịta ọhịa ijide ha. N'ezie, n'ụbọchị ndị a, anyị kwesịrị ichegbu onwe anyị banyere ụmụ mmadụ.* N'oge Arribada - nke pụtara 'ịbịarute' na Spanish - ọtụtụ puku Ridleys olive na erute n'ụsọ oké osimiri iji mee akwụ. Ndị ọkà mmụta sayensị amabeghị ihe mere ha ji eme nke a.

N'ikpeazụ, ọ bụ oge ịhapụ ma laghachi n'ala nri m. Aga m etinye otu afọ ma ọ bụ abụọ n'ebe ahụ, iri nri na iwuli ume iji laghachi na Gahirmatha. N'aka nke ọzọ, mbe mmiri Green, mgbe ụfọdụ, na-eri nri afọ ise ma ọ bụ afọ isii tupu ya enwee ume iji mee ya njem ọzọ ime akwu.
Ka m na-apụ, echere m banyere ụmụaka ndị m hapụ. Ruo ụbọchị iri ise na iri isii, akwa ahụ ga-anọgide n'okpuru ájá, anyanwụ na-enwu. Ma otu ụbọchị, ha ga-egbu ya, meghe oghere ha. Ha ga-agbakọta ọnụ, ihe karịrị otu narị nwa mbe mmiri n'okpuru ájá, na-eche ka anyanwụ daa na ka ájá jụkwa oyi.Mgbe ahụ, n'ọchịchịrị, mgbe ọ dị mma, ha ga-apụta, n'otu oge. Ha ga-ahụ ka ọnwa na-asọpụ n'oké osimiri, ma mara ụzọ nke ha ga-aga. Oga adi'nma na ha agaghị ahụ ọkụ ọzọ iji duhie ha.
Ha ga-egwu mmiri megide ebili mmiri ma daba n'okpuru mmiri ozuzo na-abịanụ.

Oh, a ga-enwe nnukwu azụ na obere azụ ga-achọ inweta ha, ugo na anụmanụ ndị ọzọ, ma ụfọdụ ga-apụ. Gaa n'oké osimiri ebe ha ga-ahụ obere obere ugbo si na ahịhịa ndị na-eto n'oké osimiri ahụ, nkea bu ụlọ ha na-ese n'elu ala ruo ọtụtụ afọ.  Mgbe ahụ, ha ga-etolite, ma eleghị anya, ha ga-abịa na ebe n'na nri nri m. Ikekwe anyị ga-ezute, ọ bụ ezie na agaghị m ama ha.
N'agbanyeghị nke ahụ, enwere m obi ụtọ n'ịmara na ha nọ n'ebe ahụ, nakwa na n'otu ụbọchị, ha ga-alaghachi dịka m gaa n'ụsọ osimiri a iji dọọ àkwá ha, ma malite usoro ndụ dị ebube ugboro ugboro.

Otu ozi si n'aka ndị mbe mmiri Olive Ridley Mbe mmiri nọ n'ihe ize ndụ n'ụwa, n'ihi ọtụtụ ihe. A na-egbu ụfọdụ mbe mmiri maka anụ ha, bụ nke a na-eji emeofe mbe mmiri.  

A na-eji azụ mbe mmiri Hawksbill mee ngwaahịa dị ka mbadamba ugogbe anya na
na ihe ndị ọzọ

Ọtụtụ ndị na-eri anụ na ụmụ mbe mmiri. Ma'na nsogbu kachasị na-abịa site na ịkụ azụ. Ọtụtụ mbe mmri ka a na-enweta na mberede n'ụgbụ azu dị iche iche, ha na-da mmiri, ma nwụọ.
N'India, e nwere ọtụtụ ndị na-echekwa nchebe na-agbalị ịchekwa nduru azụ. Ị nwere ndị dị otú ahụ na mba gị?

Kedu ihe ị ga - eme iji chekwaa mbe mmiri? Ọ bụrụ na ị bi nso n'ụsọ osimiri ebe nduru na-abata akwụ: 

• Nyere aka mee ka osimiri dị ọcha ka nne na nwa mbe mmiri ghara ịnwe ihe mgbu.
Kụzie ndị okenye nọ n'ógbè gị banyere otú ọkụ dị n'akụkụ osimiri nwere ike isi na-emerụ ndị mba mmiri ahụ. Mgbe ha pụta ha na-achọpụta ebe oké osimiri dị site na ihe ngosi nke ọnwa na mmiri, ya mere ọ bụrụ na ihe ndị ọzọ na-enwu ma obu na'gbaa ọkụ na mpaghara ahụ, ha nwere ike inwe mgbagwoju anya ma kpafuo, banye n'ime ihe ize ndụ.
• Chọpụta ma ọ bụrụ na obodo gị nwere otụ ndị na-ele ma hụ maka mbe mmiri ị nwere ike isonyere ha. 
Ma ọ bụrụ na ịnọghị nso 
n'akụkụ osimiri: Gụkwuo banyere mbe mmiri ma gwa onye ọ bụla ị maara banyere ihe ize ndụ ndị na-eche ha na ihu. Ịgbasa mgbasa ozi bụ nnukwu akụkụ nke nchekwa mbe mmiri

English:
It’s a big job, it’s number one priority and number two is
pretty important too, because you can never ignore nature’s call.
So when you gotta go, you gotta go! Some people can do this business
inside their houses, some have to go outside. Some pour water after
it’s done, others need not. It’s different in different parts of
the world, just as it was different at different times in history.

Toilets of the past

A very long time ago, more than 3,000 years ago,
the people of Indus Valley had beautiful houses with toilets built
inside them. People could finish their business in privacy and pour a
bucket of water which would flush the waste down a drain. This way,
they managed to keep their houses and streets clean.

The Indus Valley, situated in present day Pakistan and India, is one of the three oldest civilizations that we know of, the other two being Ancient Egypt and Mesopotamia. From what we can see of the ruins today, the people of Indus Valley had great building skills, were good at making metal and ceramic products, and planned their city-wide drainage systems very elaborately.

Around the same time, similar toilet arrangements were present in
other parts of the world. Homes in Egypt and Babylonia had toilets
built in, and the ruins in Skara Brae in Scotland and the Minoan
Crete in the Mediterranean show plenty of pipes leading out of what
definitely seems like a toilet inside a house. 


A little later, about 2,000 years ago in Rome, people used public
toilets. A long slab of stone had keyhole-shaped cuts at intervals.
People would sit on these openings and do their toilet business while
having a friendly chat with the person next to them. I told you it
was a “public” toilet!

How did they clean themselves, do you wonder? After I tell you, you
might wish you had never wondered. 



They took a long stick that had a sponge attached to one end and
dipped the sponge into water, and then used it to wipe their
backsides. After they felt clean, they simply handed the stick over
to their neighbour, who dipped it in water and used it again. Let me
give you a friendly tip here – if you ever find yourself in this
place, make sure you pick the very first seat!

Not everyone had to poop in public in Rome. If you were super-rich,
you would have a chamber pot at home into which you would do your
business. Once done, you would simply empty the contents onto the
street outside. And if someone happened to walk by at the time, well,
too bad for them!

About 500 years ago, Queen Elizabeth of England had a toilet
constructed inside her house. It had a pipe leading out into a sewage
pit outside. But she never used it much because the stench from the
sewer filled the toilet and she could not even breathe. So back to
the chamber pot she went.

Toilets of the present
Toilets these days don’t stink. How did they achieve that? In 1775,
the English inventor Alexander Cumming figured out a way. Instead of
using a straight pipe to connect the toilet to the sewage line, he
made it S-shaped. This made sure that while poop and pee and water
can go 

down
the drain, no
smell can come back up. Have you noticed that a little
water always stays in the toilet even after flushing? This is what
creates the "seal" and prevents the foul smell from entering the
room through the drain.

Just like olden times, different parts of the world today have
different kinds of toilets.Some places don’t have toilets at all.
Some toilets are made for sitting, some are made for squatting. Some
have a bucket with water for flushing, others have a tank filled with
water and a handle that releases the water. Some toilets have paper
to wipe the backside, some have a tap or a bucket of water to wash
up.

There are some toilets that don’t use water at all. Like the ones
on a plane. With all the turbulence, you certainly don’t want any
water in the toilet bowl! The waste is removed by a powerful vacuum
and stored in a tank below. After the plane lands, the waste is
disposed of.

There are also waterless toilets on the ground. They were designed
and built for places without easy access to water, such as remote
villages in Tamil Nadu and Maharashtra. They have been working well,
so wouldn’t it be a good idea to have such toilets everywhere?
Because the less water
we use, and
the less sewage we create, the better for the planet, right?

Toilets of the future

How do you make a waterless toilet?

The first step is to make sure that you don’t let the urine and the
faeces mix. No it’s not as gross as it sounds – it just needs the
pot to be designed in a clever way. Like having a sloping bamboo mat
act as a sieve that will allow the waste water to pass through, but
can hold the poop and send it to a different pit.

Since urine by itself is not harmful (it’s only the bacteria that
collect on open urine that cause the smell and the hazard), it can be
safely let into the ground or put to use. Here’s how: Hydrogen can
be separated from the urine and used to fuel a generator.Urine also has nitrogen, phosphorus and potassium that are great
ingredients for fertilizers.Now that urine is taken care of, what do we do with the solid waste?
Well, if it is properly mixed with ash and grass, and allowed to rest
in a pit, millions of bacteria will break it down into perfectly
useful compost for agriculture.

These toilets will help us build a world where there is no "waste." Instead it is turned into something of use. If
all houses in a city have such toilets, no sewage comes out of them,
no expensive sewage treatment plants are necessary and no sewage will
flow through the drains into lakes and rivers! What a great future for everyone!

Congratulations! You have entered one of
the best toilets of all time! So you get to roll the die again. If
you roll 2,4,6 move that many spaces forward. If you roll 1,3,5 you
can pick any pawn on the board (other than yours) and move it that
many spaces back.

waterless toilet! Take the short-cut!

Igbo: Ọ bụ nnukwu ọrụ, ọ bụ otu ihe kacha mkpa, nke abụọ dịkwa mkpa, n'ihi na ị gaghị eleghara oku ahụ anya. Ya mere, mgbeị na-aga, ị ga-aga!Ụfọdụ ndị mmadụ nwere ike ịme ya n'ime ụlọ ha, ụfọdụ ga-aga n'èzí. Ụfọdụ na wụsa mmiri mgbe ha mechara ya, ndị ọzọ adịghị mkpa. Ọ dị iche iche na akụkụ ụwa, dịka ọ dị iche na oge dị iche iche n'akụkọ ihe mere eme.

Mposi nke oge gara agaOgologo oge gara aga, ihe karịrị puku afọ atọ gara aga, ndị ndagwurugwu Indus nwere ụlọ ndị mara mma na ụlọ mposi na n'ime ha. Ndị mmadụ nwere ike ime mposi na nzuzo ma wụsa mmiri nke gawepụ ihe mkpofu.
. N'ụzọ dị otú a, ha jisiri ike na-edebe ụlọ na n'okporo ámá ọcha.

Ndagwurugwu Indus, nke dị ugbu a na mpaghara Pakistan na India, bụ otu n'ime obodo ochie kachasị ochie anyị maara, nke abụọ ndị ọzọ bụ Ijipt oge ochie na Mesopotemia. Site na ihe anyị nwere ike ịhụ banyere mkpọmkpọ ebe 
ahụ taa
ndị ndagwurugwu Indus nwere nnukwu nkà ụlọ, dị mma n'ịmepụta ígwè na ngwaahịa seramiiki, ma hazie usoro iwepu ihe mpofu nke obodo ha n'ụzọ zuru ezu

N'ime oge ahụ, usoro ụlọ mposi dị otú ahụ dị n'akụkụ ndị ọzọ nke ụwa. Ụlọ ndị dị n'Ijipt na Babilọn nwere ụlọ mposi e wuru na ya, mkpọmkpọ ebe ndị dị na Skara Brae na Scotland na Minoan Crete dị na Mediterenian gosipụtara ọtụtụ ụbọkọ na-eduga na ihe yiri ka ụlọ mposi n'ime ụlọ.Obere oge, ihe dị ka afọ 2,000 gara aga na Rom, ndị mmadụ na-aga na ụlọ mposi ọha na eze. Ogologo nkume  nwere oghere mkpịsị iche iche n'etiti. Ndị mmadụ ga-anọdụ ala n'èzí ndị a ma rụọ ọrụ ụlọ mposi ha na onye na-esote ha na-akparịta ụka. Agwara m gị na ọ bụ ụlọ mposi "ọha"!

Kedu ka ha si mee ka onwe ha dị ọcha ma ha mecha mposi, ị na-eche kwa nke a? Mgbe m gwasịrị gị, ị nwere ike ịchọọ ka ị na-eche zi kwa nka.Ha weere ogologo osisi nke nwere ihe dị ka ogbo nke dị na n'otu njedebe wee tinye n'ome mmiri nkedị n'ebe
 ahụ, ha wee jiri ya mee ka ọ mechapu ike mposi ha.Mgbe ha chere na ha dị ọcha, ha na-enyefe osisi ahụ n'aka onye agbata obi ha, bụ onye ga etinye kwa ya na otu mmiri ahụ weejiri ya mecha kwa ike mposiọzọ. Biko ka m gwa gị ihe ị ga-esi nwee obi ụtọ - ọ bụrụ na ịchọta onwe gị na ebe a, jisi ike ka-ewere oche mbụ!

Ọ bụghị onye ọ bụla ga-eme mposi na ona na eze na Rom. Ọ bụrụ na ị bara nnukwu ọgaranya, ị ga-enwe ite n'ime ụlọ ị ga na ejị eme mposi. Ozugbo emechara, ị ga etufu mposi gi ahụ n'èzí. nwereọkpọkọ na-eduba n'ime olulu mmiri n'èzí. Ma, ọ dịghị mgbe ọ na-eji ya eme mposi n'ihi na ísì ọjọọ nke si n'ebe ahụ dị oke n'ime ụlọ mposi ya, ọ laghachiri iji ite we're na eme mposi.

 Nke a mere mposi na mmamịrị nwere ike ịdata na-ebe nkpofu mposi ahụ, enweghị isi nwere ike ịlaghachi azụ. Ị chọpụtala na obere mmiri na-anọ n'ụlọ mposi mgbe ọ ịmecha ma me ka mmiri puta buru mposi

Dịka oge ochie, akụkụ dị iche iche nke ụwa taa nwere ụdị ụlọ mposi dịgasị iche iche.Ụfọdụ ebe enweghị ebe mposi ọ bụla. Ụfọdụ na-eme ụlọ mposi maka ịnọ ọdụ, ụfọdụ na-eme ka ha hulata ala. Ụfọdụ nwere igbe na mmiri maka nsị, ndị ọzọ nwere tanki jupụtara na mmiri na ihe na-emepụta mmiri ahụ. Ụfọdụ ụlọ mposi nwere akwụkwọ iji kpochapụ azụ, ụfọdụ nwere mgbata ma ọ bụ ite mmiri iji saa ahụ

E nwere ụlọ mposi ndị anaghị eji mmiri mee ihe ọ bụla. Dị ka ndị nọ n'ụgbọelu. A na-ewepụ ihe mkpofu site na ike dị ike ma debe ya na tank n'okpuru. Mgbe ụgbọelu da n'ala, a na-ekpofu ihe niile a.
E nwekwara ụlọ mposi n'elu ala nke na-ejighi mmiri ma ọlị eme. A haziri ha maka ebe enweghi ike inweta mmiri, dika obodo nta di na Tamil Nadu na Maharashtra na India. Ha na-arụ ọrụ nke ọma, ya mere ọ gaghị adị mma ịnweta ụlọ mposi dị otú ahụ n'ebe nile?

 Dị ka ịnweta ngwu achara dị ka nnọchibido nke ga-ekwe ka mmiri mmiri na-agabiga, ma nwere ike ijide mposi wee zipu ya na olulu dị iche

na ebe ọ bụla na-asọba n'ime ọdọ mmiri obodo uwa nile! Lee ọdịnihu dị ukwuu maka onye ọ bụla!

English: Late one night, when her Amma and Achan are fast asleep, Maisha grabs her goggles and sneaks out of the house.Maisha loves the beach at night. And one of her best friends lives in the sea.

Maisha goes to their usual meeting place on the beach and calls out.“Uchli! Are you here?”She can sit here for hours, watching Uchli fly in and out of the water. Uchli is a flying fish who loves to show off his tricks.
But today, Uchli looks worried.“What’s the matter?” Maisha asks. “Why do you look so upset?”“Can’t you see?” he says. “The moon is missing!”

The moon! Uchli is right—their friend is not in the sky tonight. In fact, there’s a big hole where the moon should be.“But we saw her just last night,” Maisha exclaims. “She rose from the sea right here in front of us... Do you think she’s lost underwater?”“We have to find her!” Uchli says.

“But how will we see anything without the moonlight?” Maisha asks.


Just then, Uchli notices something in the water. Every time a wave breaks in the distance, little sparks of light glow and fade and glow again.
“Maisha!” he shouts, excited. “I have an idea! Get on my back, let’s go to those waves over there.”When they reach the lights, Maisha takes a deep breath, holds Uchli tightly and . . .
Maisha gasps. She feels like she’s floating in a sky full of stars! There are tiny creatures glowing all around her.“Wow, who are they?” she whispers to Uchli.

“They’re plankton. Maybe they can help light our way in the sea!” Uchli says.



“Will you share your light with us?” Maisha asks one of them. “The moon is missing, and we need some light to find her.”
“You will need more than just my light,” the plankter says. “Let me ask my friends if they can help too!”


Soon, Maisha and Uchli are joined by an army of little creatures, with their flickering lights.
“Now where can the moon be?” Maisha wonders.

“I can help you,” a deep, booming voice says, near Maisha's ear.She spins around. The eight arms of a firefly squid glimmer back at her. His body is covered in neon-blue lights.“I saw the moon go this way just a little while ago.” At first, Maisha is scared of the long tentacles. But she knows the firefly squid’s light can help them see better underwater.
“Lead the way,” she says.The squid wraps a tentacle around Maisha's finger. “Hold on tight!”

Then Maisha, Uchli, the glowing plankton and the firefly squid all swim down together.Down, down, down they go where to the water is very dark. But the plankton glow brighter, and the squid flashes his light.There is still no moon in sight.  Then they meet an anglerfish, out on a hunt. She has sharp teeth, but Maisha is not scared any more.
“Hello,” she says. “We’re looking for the moon. Have you seen her around?”“Yes,” says the anglerfish. “I saw her swimming with some moonfish a few hours ago. Follow me!”
Maisha, Uchli, the squid and the plankton follow the green lure of the anglerfish.The light from the glowing animals falls like a spotlight on the dark ocean floor.

Suddenly, Maisha sees something bright under a rock.It’s the moon!“Help,” squeaks the moon. “I’m stuck!”The squid lifts the rock with his tentacles.“Hurrah!” everyone shouts, as the pale moon slips out.

“What happened?” Uchli asks.“I came here to meet my cousins, the moonfish,” says the moon. “I got lost on my way back when my light began to fade. And then I got stuck under this rock. Thank you for coming to find me.”

“So this is where you are when you’re not in the sky!” Maisha says.



The moon smiles and begins to float up towards the surface. Finally, she jumps into the sky.
Uchli and Maisha wave goodbye to their new friends and swim back to the beach in the moonlight.The stars under the sea continue to shine deep into the night.
MEET THE LIGHT-MAKERSDid you know that many animals, both above and under water, are able to make their own light?

The tiny plankton that Maisha and Uchli meet glow to scare away the animals that might eat them. When they sense movement in the water, the plankton let out bright sparks as a warning. Sometimes, waves and boat traffic also trigger this light.


While plankton animals have a chemical in them that helps them glow, the firefly squid has special organs called photophores that produce its light. Thousands of these light-producing photophores on the squid’s body flash to attract food, impress a mate or confuse predators.

The lures of anglerfish get their light from the glowing bacteria that live inside them.



Many plants and animals glow above the water too. Fireflies, some mushrooms, and even you emit a tiny amount of light every day!
Igbo:
N'otu abali, ka chi jimichara, Maisha weere enyoanya ya si n'ụlọ ha zopụ, mgbe nne na nna ya na-arahụ ụra. 

Maisha na-enwe mmasị ịga n'ebe a na-egwu egwu n'akụkụ oshimiri n'abalị.  Otu n'ime ndị bụ ezi enyi ya nwanyị bi n'oshimiri.

Ọ na-abụ Maisha gaa n'ebe ahụ a na-egwu egwu n'akụkụ oshimiri, ya kpọọ Uchili oku, sị:

"Uchili, Ị nọ n'ebe a?"

Maisha were ike ịnọdụ ala n'ebe a ọtụtụ awa na-elele ka Uchili si-esi n'ime mmiri na-efepụta n'efebakwa. Uchili bụ azụ na-efe efe, nke na-enwe mmasị ime amansi.

﻿Mana tàà, obi adịghị Uchili nma.

Maisha wee jụọ ya sị, "Nkea ihu gị gbarụrụ otu a, gịnị mere?"

Uchili zara Maisha sị, "Ọ bụ na ịhụghị na ọnwa efùola?"

Uchili kwuru eziokwu na enyi ha ọnwa anọghị n'igwe n'abalị a. N'ezie, ọ bụ nnukwu oghere nọ n'ebe ọnwa kwesịrị ịnọ.

Maisha wee welie olu sị, "Mana anyị hụrụ ya n'abalị ụnyaahụ. Anyị nọ n'ebea na-ele ya anya o si na mmiri chapụta. I chere na o furu n'ala mmiri?"

Ichili wee sị, "Anyị ga-achọ ya."

Mana otua ìhè-ọnwa na anọghị, kedụ ka anyị ga-esi hụ ụzọ chọọ ya?" Nkea bụ ajụjụ Maisha jụrụ. 
 Uchili sị ya chere na o nwere ihe ya hụrụ n'ime mmírí. 


 Mgbe ọbụla ebili mmiri tiri n'ebe dị anya, ìhè na-acha nwantịị, nyụọ, chakwaa nwantịị ọzọ.

Uchili wee tie mkpu n'ọṅụ sị, "Maisha! Lee ihe anyị ga-eme. Rigoro m n'azụ ka anyị gakwuru ebili mmiri ndị ahụ nọ n'ofè nke ọzọ."

Mgbe ha ruru ebe ìhè ebili mmiri ndị ahụ nọ, Maisha jisiri Uchili aka ike, kuba ume ekuba...

Maisha bido tụba ume. Ọ dị ya ka ha n'ese n'eluigwe kpakpando jupụtara na ya, nihi na ụmụ ihe na-amụke ka kpakpando na-efegharị gburugburu ya.

Na mmasị, ya jiri olu nwayọ jụọ Uchili, "Ole ndị bụ ndịa?"

Uchili zara ya sị, "Ha bụ plankụtịn (plankton), bụ ụmụ irighiri ānụmanụ̀ na-amụke ọkụ n'elu mmiri. Ma eleghị anya, ha ga-enye anyị ìhè otua anyị na-aba n'ime oshimiri."  Maisha jụrụ otu plankụtịn sị ya, " Ị ga-ekwe ka anyị soro ìhè gị? Ọnwa furu. Anyị chọrọ ìhè anyị ga-eji hụ ụzọ chọọ ya?"

PPlankụtịn ahụ zara Maisha sị, "Ìhè m nanị agaghị ezu. Ka m rịọ ndị enyi m ka ha wetakwa nke ha." 
O teghị anya, igurube plankụtịn were ìhè ha bịa soro Maisha na Uchili.

Maisha wee na-atule, "Ebee ka ọnwa nọ ugbua?"

Otu olu na-asụ̀ ka udu dara n'akụkụ ntị Maisha sị, "M ga-enyere unu aka." Maisha tụgharịrị. Ọ bụrụ skwidi (squid), anụ mmiri na-ebu ìhè ka ụkpala mmụmụọkụ,  weere aka asatọ ya chee Maisha n'ihu. Ìhè-ọkụ na-acha bluu bluu jupụtara skwidi ahụ̀ n'ahụ.

Skwidi sịrị, "O tebeghị anya m hụrụ ka ọnwa gara ụzọ a."

N'agbanyeghị na Maisha tụrụ egwu na mbụ, ọ matara na ìhè si skwidi ahụ n'ahụ apụta ga-enyere ha aka ịhụ ụzọ n'ime mmiri.

Maisha wee sị skwidi, "Ngwa, nọrọ n'ihu na-edu anyị." 
 Skwidi were otu aka ya kedo na mkpịsị aka Maisha, sị ya, " Jidesie ya ike."

Maisha, Uchili, plankụtịn na-amụke ka kpakpando, na skwidi mmụmụọkụ wee gwubaa n'ime mmiri. Ha wee na-egwuba, na-egwuba, na-egwuba ruo ebe mmiri gbara ezigbo ọchịchịrị. Ìhè plankụtịn wee mụkee karịa. Skwidi na-enyekwa ìhè nke ya.  Mana n'ebee ka ị hụrụ ọnwa? 
Ka ha na-aga, ha zute azụ̀ aha ya bụ angụlafish (anglerfish) pụtara ịchọ ihe ọ ga-eri. O nwere eze na-aghọ nkọ, mana egwu a naghị atụzi Maisha.

O wee sị angụlafish, "Di anyị, ị hụrụ ọnwa? Anyị na-achọ ya." 
Angụlafish sị ya, "Ee. Awa olemole gara aga ka m hụrụ ya na ụfọdụ munfish ka ha na-egwugharị. Sobenụ m."

Ka angụlafish chaara ọkụ akwụkwọ ndụ akwụkwọ ndụ ya na-egwu mmiri na-aga, Maisha, Uchili, skwidi na igurube plankụtịn ana-eso ya. 
 Ìhè si n'ahụ ụmụ anụmanụ ndịa amụke bịara chado zaaa n'ala oshimiri ahụ gbara ọchịchịrị.

Na mberede, Maisha hụ ihe na-egbuke n'okpuru nkumè. Ọ bụ onwa! Ọnwa tie oke nkpu, "Nyenụ aka. A tọrọ m atọ." Skwidi were aka ogologo asatọ ya bulie nkumè ahụ. 
Ka
 ọnwa mịpụtara, onye ọbụla tie "Hureee!"

Uchili jụọ ọnwa sị, "Gịnị mere?" 
Ọnwa zara sị, "A bịara m ịhụ munfish ha, bụ ụmụ nwanne papa m. Ìhè m gbadaa. A hụghịzi m ụzọ, wee sọrọ ishi ga-atọ na nkumè. Daalụnụ maka ịchọro m bịa."

Maisha wee jụọ ya, "Ya bụ n'ebea ka ị nọ mgbe ị na anọghị n'igwe?" 

Ọnwa mụọ amụ, wee malite seliwe, pụba n'elu mmiri.

N'ikpeazụ, ya awụgoro n'igwe.

Uchili na Maisha wee feere ndị enyi ha baị baị, sị ha ka ọ dịnụ oge ọzọ. Ha abụọ gwuru mmiri laghachị n'ebe a na-egwu egwu n'akụkụ oshimiri (beach). Kpakpando wee na-acha n'okpuru oshimiri ruo n'ime ime abalị.

ZUTE NDỊ NA-EME ÌHÈ 
 Ị maara na ọtụtụ ụmụ anụmanụ, ndị bi n'elu nakwa ndị bi na mmiri, na-emepụtanwu ìhè nke ha?

Irighiri plankụtịn ndị ahụ Maisha zutere na-amụke ọkụ iji chụọ ụmụ anụmanụ ndị ga-achọ iri ha ka nri. Mgbe ọbụla ha nụrụ nkpọtụ na mmiri, oge ụfọdụ ọ bụrụ ebili mmiri ma ọ bụ nkpọtụ ụgbọ mmiri, ụmụ plankụtịn achaa ọkụ iji dọọ ihe mere nkpọtụ aka na ntị. Ọ bụ kemikal nọ n'ahụ plankụtịn na-emepụta ọkụ ahụ, mana ọkụ ma ọ bụ ìhè nke skwidi na-esite na ihe pụrụ iche dị ya n'ahụ, a na-akpọ fotofọ (photophore, na Bekee). Puku kwuru puku fotofọ ndịa na-amụke ọkụ ha iji ratara skwidi anụmanụ ndị ọ ga-eri. Ìhè ọkụ ahụ na-emekwa ka skwidi ọzọ nwee mmasị ịbịa ka ya na nwanna ya mekọrịta. Ọrụ ọzọ ìhè ahụ na-arụ bụ ime ka anụmanụ ndị nwere ike iri skwidi nọrọ na mgbagwoju anya ga-eme ka ha hapụ ịga skwidi nso.

Ìhè nke angụlafish na-ewepụta na-esite na ụmụ nje bakụteria (bacteria) bi n'ime ha. Ọtụtụ osisi na ụmụ anụmanụ na-amụke ọkụ n'elu mmiri. 
Ụkpala mmụmụọkụ (fireflies) na ụfọdụ ero, tinyekwara anyị bụ mmadụ na-ewepụta ntakịrị ìhè n'ahụ ụbọchị niile.

English: Blue tongueBlack tongue

Long tongue
Strong tongue

Spiky tongue
Sticky tongue
Rough tongue Smooth tongue
Forked tongue Fast tongue
Heavy tongue Hairy tongue

What is YOUR tongue
like?

Let’s talk about tonguesDid you know that tongues are made of muscle and are able to do many different things? Yet tongues never get tired or sore!Polar Bear’s blue tongue absorbs the sun’s heat to keep warm.Giraffe’s tongue is dark, which protects it from sunburn in the African savannah.Pangolin puts its long tongue into anthills to slurp up ants
–
its favorite snack.

Salamander shoots out its powerful tongue to snatch crickets and fruit flies.Goose grips grass with its spiky tongue and tears it off to munch.Frog catches flies with its sticky saliva and stretchy tongue.
Cat’s rough tongue helps it brush its fur.Dog cools off by sticking out its tongue that swells up when it gets too hot.Snake uses its forked tongue to smell its surroundings.

Chameleon’s tongue darts out with lightning speed to grab that grasshopper before it leaps away.Blue Whale, the largest animal on Earth, has the heaviest tongue that helps trap tiny krill that it loves to eat.Flamingo’s hairy tongue helps filter blue-green algae and shrimps that are its favourite food.

English:
One elephant is
going to drink water.
Two giraffes are going to drink water.

Three buffaloes
and four birds are also going to drink water.
Five antelopes and warthogs are walking to the water.
Seven zebras are running to the water.
Eight frogs and nine fish are swimming in the water.
One lion roars. He also wants to drink. Who is afraid of the lion?
One elephant is drinking water with the lion.
Igbo: Otu enyi na-aga ịṅụ mmiri.
Anu ogologo onu abuo na-aga inu mmiri.
Edi ọhịa atọ na nnụnụ anọ na-aga aṅụ mmiri.
Ele ise na - anu n'ebi na akuku mmiri na-eje  na mmiri.
Anyinya nwere akara akara asaa ji ọsọ agbaga na mmiri.
Mbara asatọ na azụ itoolu na-egwu mmiri n'ime mmiri.
Otu ọdụm na-ebigbọ. Ọ chọkwara ịṅụ mmiri. Ònye na-atụ egwu ọdụm?
Otu enyi na odum na-aṅụ mmiri  .

English: Hi! I am Neema. Just like you, I love to eat. Here are are some things that I eat: Dhokla , Panipuri and Jalebi.
Yum Yum! Where is this noise coming from? Oh! it's Neema who is eating.
Neema loves mangoes.
She loves all fruits.
It is raining. What is Neema doing? Let us see.
Oh! Neema is eating jamuns, pineapples and corn.Yummy! She says.
Oh! it is winter.Let us see what Neema is doing.
Oh! Neema is eating custard apple , beetroot and imlis
Neema loves to eat. Just like us.
Igbo:

Nnenna ji na-eri nri  mgbe niile
CHOMP! CHOMP!CHEW ... CHEW!MMM ... MMM!Oho! Mechie ọnụ gị mgbe ị na-eri nri, Nnenna!
Mgbe ọ bụ ọkọchị,Ụbọchị  ana-enwe obi ụtọ na ogologo oge,Ọ na-ekpo ọkụ n'èzí.Kedu ihe Nnenna na-eri taa?

Oge okpomọkụ bụ oge iri nri mango na -acha edo edo, akwụkwọ ndụ akwụkwọ ndụ na uhie uhie.Lychees na-acha ocha na ami ami ma buru  uwe na-acha uhie uhie,egwusi mmiri akara akara na-acha akwukwo ndu akwukwo ndu na  odo odo,Mkpụrụ osisi udara na-ato uto n'onu,Oho! Aka Nnenna niile na-acha anunu anunu agwakota ya n'ojii ugbu a!
Mgbe mmiri ozuzo,Igwe ojii gbara ọchịchịrị ma na-agbagharị agbagọ,Mmiri na-ezo n'èzí.Kedu ihe Nnenna na-eri taa?

Oge mmiri ozuzo bụ oge iri oka na-acha edo edo, ọcha na anunu anunu agwakota ojii.oroma nkirisi di ohụrụ na kemmiri ihe ụtọ,nkwu aba bu  okpueze n'isi ha,ube na-acha anunu anunu agwakota ojii.Oho! Ire Nnenna  na-acha ọkụ na-acha anụnụ anụnụ!
Mgbe oyi,Na ụbọchị di nkenke.Ma oyi na-atụ n'èzí.Kedu ihe Nnenna  na-eri taa?

Oge oyi bụ oge maka akwụkwọ nri na-egbu maramara.Beetroot, ọbara ọbara dị ka anyanwụ dara,udara akwụkwọ ndụ akwụkwọ ndụ.Lee, lee, Nnenna na-arigo n'elu osisi ugbu a,Oho! Ọ na-aghota oroma uto niile na-
acha akwukwo ndu akwukwo nduma na egbuke egbuke!
Nnenna nwere mmasị iri nri,Ma ọ na-enwe mmasị iri nri n'oge ahụ!CHOMP! CHOMP!CHEW ... CHEW!MMM ... MMM!
N'ebe ụwa niile, e nwere ụdị oge ise -Oge  Mmiri, oge mkpomoku, oke mmiri, uguru na oke oyi. Ma na ụfọdụ ebe Naijiria, dịka ebe Nnenna bi, oge ndị a bụ udu mmiri na okochi.

Rie na oge!Dịka Nnenna, ị nwere ike iri mkpụrụ osisi na akwụkwọ nri dị ụtọ na afọ. Nke a bụ oge kalenda oge iji mara na mkpụrụ osisi na akwụkwọ nri i  ga-eri n'afọ.                                  Udara: Jenụwarị ruo February                                  Mangoes: 
Jenụwarị  ruo February na May na July                                              Ube: March ruo May na October ruo November
Akwụkwọ ugu: March ruo May, na October ruo JanuaryOka: March ruo AugustOroma: April ruo June
Ahu ekere: onwa may ruo onwa June
Oroma nkirisi: July-AugustUdara: October-FebruaryBeetroot: O na-adi n'afọ niile, mana ana eri ya n'oge oyi

English:
Today is my first day of school. Mother held my hand and walking with me. "Now I have grown up," I say. "Come...come!"
Mother held my hand tightly.

There are many children near the school.
Some come by bus. Some come by car.
Some come by rickshaw. Some come by bicycle and some come on foot, like me.

We reached to the gate.
Mother left my hand.
She stopped on gate. I have to go alone inside.
Many unknown faces are around me.

I moved one step. I moved another step.  
I looked behind. As I move forward, mother looks smaller. Would she disappeared? I ran to her. I don't think I've grown up. I hold her hand and say, "don't go".

All had gone inside. Only I was outside. Teacher came outside.
She smiles after looking me. I also smiles. Mother says," Rani I will meet you here when you come out". I leave her hand. She waive her hand.
I ran inside. Mother would meet there on leave.
Igbo: Ọ bụ ụbọchị mbụ m n'ụlọ akwụkwọ.Mama m na-ejide aka m ma soro m gaa n'okporo ụzọ na ụlọ akwụkwọ."Ana m etolite ugbu a," ka m kwuru. "Biko, hapụ aka m!"

E nwere ọtụtụ ụmụ na'abia ụlọ akwụkwọ.Ha na-abịa site na  n'ụgbọala 
dị iche iche 

Ha na-agagharị
n'ebe nile

ụfọdụ ha na-eje ije, dị ka m.

Anyị rutere ọnụ ụzọ ámá nke ụlọ akwụkwọ. Nnem we're hapụ m n'aka.Ọ nọ n'ọnụ ụzọ ámá 
ahụ.
M ga-aga n'ime naanị m.E nwere ọtụtụ ihu ọhụrụ gbara m gburugburu.

Eje'm ije otu nzọụkwụ. M na-eje ije nzọụkwụ ọzọ. N'we lee anya n'azụ. Nne na-aga ije pụọ. Ọ ga-apụ n'anya ruo mgbe ebighị ebi? Agbaghachiri'm 
azụ
.Achọghị m ka m tolite. M' jide aka ya.

"Agala," ka m kwuru!

Onye ọ bụla nọ n'ime ụlọ akwụkwọ ugbu a. Ọ bụ naanị m nọ n'èzí. Onye nkụzi ahụ apụta. Ọ na-amụmụ ọnụ ọchị nye m. M na-alaghachi azụ. Nne m na-ekwu, "Raluchukwu, m ga-anọ ebe a mgbe ị pụta." 
Ahapụ'm aka ya. Ọ efere'm aka.
Agba ba'm n'ime ụlọ akwụkwọ. Nne m ga-anọ ebe ahụ mgbe ụlọ akwụkwọ gasịrị!

la, la, la, la, la…”

“Is it black?”“Is it white?”“It is brown!”
“La-la, la, la, la, la, laa …”
“Is it a prayer?”“Is it a poem?”“It is a song!”

“La-la, la, la, la, la, la…”
“It is a donkey!”“It is a donkey!”“It is a donkey, sing on!”

English: My awesome Ajji makes delicious laddoos , I asked Ajji ," May i Please have these yummy for my tummy Laddoos?"She my heart as she uttered,"Not now, beta, may be a little later, not today though, you will get it tomorrow."But I had no patience so ,I could not wait till tomorrow

With a heavy heart i thought for the park i asked Ajja ," May I go out to play with my friends?" he got me into his sweet lovely trap, he simply said," Little later you may go my chap, before that you have to take your nap." But I had no patience to wait till the nap

Then i saw my superman dress,With all my heart i went to mom to address," Can i wear my new costume and do my zip,. zap, zooom"  O her words cleared my doubt when she plainly refused saying you may wear it when we go out

The box attracted me to it right from the start,How to take permission from dad to open it is an unknown art. He refused right away and told me to simply wait. I wanted it right there i knew for sure, So I could not wait any more.
I went to bed with a heavy heart, why do they never learn to say 'yes'? why the elders cannot learn that art?I went to bed all annoyed
Next day when i entered the kitchen it was a sweet surprise. Ajji came to me with a smile She said in her volume which is usually low,," You can eat these laddoos now."

Ajja said,' bring your bat and ball, its time to hit the six  as cricket will b e played by all."Papa also gave me permission to open the box and before i thought it was a haux, I had everyone around me clapping and smiling and loudly they say," Happy Birthday !"
Igbo:
Ajụrụ m Ajji, "Biko m nwere ike ịnweta nri ụfọdụ?" 
"Ọ bụghị ugbu a, 'Buike, ma eleghị anya echi."

Ma achọghị m ichere ruo echi

Ajụrụ m Ajja, sị, "M ga-apụ gwuegwu mu'na ndị enyi m?" 
"Ọ bụghị ugbu a, Buike. Ma eleghị anya mgbe ị zuru ike? "Ma achọghị m ichere ruo mgbe m zuru cha ike.

Ajụrụ m Ma, "M ga-eyi uwe ọhụrụ ndị a?" 
"Ọ bụghị ugbu a, 'Buike, ị nwere ike eyiri ha mgbe anyị ga a'pụọ." Ma achọghị m ichere ruo mgbe anyị gawara

Ajụrụ m Papa, sị, "Enwere m ike imepe igbe ahụ dị mma? " 
"Ọ bụghị ugbu a, ọ bụghị ugbu a. Ị ghaghị ichere. " Ma achọghị m ichere ọzọ

Gini mere ndi mmadu ji ekwu mgbe nile,

'Ọ bụghị ugbu a, ọ bụghị ugbu a'? 
N'abalị ahụ, agara m na-ehi ụra na iwe iwe
N'echi ya, m biliri n'isi ụtụtụ wee banye ebe nne m na-esi nri. Ajji kwuru, "Ị nwere ike iri nri ndị a ugbu a."

Ajja kwuru, sị, "Ị nwere ike ịkpọ ndị enyi gị ugbu a." 
"Ị nwere ike iyi uwe ndị a ugbu a." Mama kwuru

Papa si, "Ị nwere ike mepee igbe a ugbu a." Ha niile wee sị, "Obi ụtọ ụbọchị ọmụmụ gi!
